loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en: Adjoa G. is a peddler of second-hand clothing at Elmina. Her husband is a petty trader. She lives with her six dependents. As part of her responsibilities, she assists her husband in paying utility bills. Her loan will be added to her initial capital to buy more quantities of clothes for resale. She hopes to reinvest the new profits.

loans.use: to buy more clothes for resale.

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en:
Letecia is a married woman with seven children. Her oldest child is 20 years old. She owns a sari-sari (variety) store business.

Letecia sells items like canned goods, oil and vinegar. She also sells purified water to the people in her community. She usually earns about 3000 PHP per month with her business.

Letecia is requesting a loan of 8000 PHP to buy more items to sell, such as purified water and noodles. In the future, Letecia hopes for her children to be successful.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell, such as purified water and noodles.

loans.name: Burambira Development Group B

texts.en:
48-year-old T. George is a gentleman who believes that entrepreneurial self-efficacy is one of the best predictors of business success. From that point of view, the happily married father of three strives to bring an upbeat line of operation to his food sales business in Kihihi in Western Uganda. This has all been backed by courage, persistence and conviction. These have given his business an edge. 

George has  mostly been selling cereals. He has done this for the last five years. He is mobile and keeps moving in many food markets in western Uganda. He says he took root in this business with a loan from a local savings group. Weekly he says his business profits total up to shillings 130,000. He says he is going to use this loan to purchase more cereals to sell.

loans.use: to purchase more cereals to sell.

loans.name: Nana Adjoa

texts.en:
Nana Adjoa A. is a baker at Elmina. She also freezes meat and fish for sale. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a driver. 

Nana pays the school fees of her children as a way of helping her husband to reduce his financial burden. Her loan will be used to buy more fish and meat to freeze for sale.  She anticipates reinvesting her new profit.

In this picture she is showing a few bagged meat items.

loans.use: to buy more fish and meat to freeze for sale.

loans.name: Helena

texts.en:
Helena A. displays smoked fish on a wooden tray for sale. She is married and has eight dependents. Her husband is a farmer. She has been a fishmonger for close to 10 years. 

Helena uses her income to assist her husband in the general upkeep of the home. Helena will use the loan to buy fish and firewood to smoke the fish for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Helena plans to add the sale of other food items to her business.

loans.use: to buy fish and firewood to smoke the fish for sale.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis aged 31, is married and they have one child. He has been a wheat farmer for the past seven years and earns a monthly income of KES. 1,000.

He learned about KADET through a registered client, and he has applied for his first loan of KES 20,000 from KADET which he plans to use to purchase wheat seeds and fertilizers. 

He hopes to make a profit and use it to purchase sheep for fattening. He dreams that he will soon be stable and his children will live better lives.

loans.use: to purchase wheat seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Tariel

texts.en:
Tariel and his wife Tsiuri live in the village of Tkachiri, Imereti Region. Tariel is 38 years old. They have two children – a 15-year-old daughter and a 14-year-old son. 

The only source of income for the family comes from agricultural activities. In particular they own two glass and one wooden greenhouses. In the period of October – May the greenhouses are used for growing greens and in the summer period cucumbers and tomatoes are grown. Greens are sold to exporters, who sell them in the neighboring countries. Cucumbers and potatoes are sold by Tariel on the local open market. 

With the requested amount Tariel plans to purchase wooden and polyethylene materials to renovate the wooden greenhouse. After the renovation the family will get better products in the harvest season. This will positively affect the income of the family.

Tariel plans to use the increase in profit for paying the study fees of their children.

loans.use: to purchase wooden and polyethylene materials for greenhouse renovation.

loans.name: Maridel

texts.en:
Maridel is a married woman with three children. She is 53 years old and has had a sari-sari (variety) store business for five years. She sells various items like coffee, detergent, soap, and sugar to the people in her community. She usually earns about 4500 PHP per month with her sari-sari store. Maridel is also an AVON dealer. She says the extra income is very helpful to her family.

Maridel is requesting a loan of 14,000 PHP to buy more items to sell, such as vinegar and sugar. She hopes to expand her sari-sari store in the future.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell, such as vinegar and sugar.

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda is a 33-year-old married woman with five children. Her oldest child is only 13 years old.

Rosalinda is a farmer and tills her own land. She has been growing rice for five years. Rosalinda earns about 3000 PHP per month from her farming business. She works hard to improve her income and be able to sustain her family.

This loan will be used by Rosalinda to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs. She hopes for this loan to help improve her harvest.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Clementine

texts.en: Clemetine is 29 years old, and she has a two-year-old child. She owns a general store in which she sells sorghum, tomatoes and berries. She has had this business for the past two years and her husband sells different kinds of items. Clementine is requesting a loan to buy tomatoes. With the profits she plans to open up a shop and put in a variety of fruits and vegetables.

loans.use: To buy tomatoes.

loans.name: Olivia

texts.en:
Olivia N. lives in the Kawaala neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has six children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (elderly parents).    

Olivia has a business of selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for seven years, and she works six days out of every week. Olivia   sells her products at the market, retail.    Olivia   has requested a loan of   800,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal.     She also generates additional income through sales of second-hand shoes and piped water.

The main business challenges for Olivia include the rainy season and transportation.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a delivery van. Olivia   lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and has access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy some animals to be able to grow his business and attract more customers.

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua G. is married and has one child. Her husband is a farmer. She makes rice porridge for sale at Elmina. Ekua uses her income to help her husband provide the basic needs of the home.

 Ekua will use the Kiva loan to purchase rice, sugar, milk, and other items used in preparing porridge. Ekua plans to plough back her new expected profit into the business.

In this picture, G. is kneeling close to the rice she uses for the rice porridge. At the time of the visit, she had finished selling for the day.

loans.use: to purchase rice, sugar, milk, etc. used in preparing porridge.

loans.name: Fatou Ndiaye Thiaka

texts.fr: Madame Fatou Ndiaye Thiaka F. est une jeune femme yoffoise de 32 ans.  Elle est mariée et mère de 3 enfants dont l’âge varie entre 3 et 10 ans. Elle évolue depuis quelques années dans le commerce de produits cosmétiques. En même temps elle gère une boutique de mercerie. Elle a choisi cette activité de commerce par passion mais aussi dans le but de se procurer des revenus  qui lui permettront de soutenir son mari dans la gestion des besoins de la famille.  Madame F. est sociétaire du guichet de Yoff depuis janvier 2011. Elle sollicite un crédit de 150 000frs prévu pour l’achat  de produits cosmétiques et de produits de mercerie qui seront destinés à  renforcer  son stock  et élargir son part du marché. Son objectif est d’améliorer la situation de vie sociale de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatou Ndiaye is 32 years old and comes from Yoff. She is married and the mother of 3 children aged between 3 and 10. For the last few years she has developed a beauty products business. At the same time, she has a shop where she sells sewing supplies.  She chose this activity because she likes it a lot but also in order to produce income that will help her husband in managing the family's needs.

Mrs. F. has been a member of the Yoff branch since January 2011. She is asking for a credit of 150,000 francs to buy beauty products and sewing supplies to increase her stock and expand her share of the market. Her goal is to improve the social aspect of her family's lifestyle.

loans.use: to buy beauty products and sewing supplies

loans.name: Rufina

texts.en:
Rufina is a married woman from the town of Trinidad, Bohol. Her husband is a farmer and primarily grows rice. She has a sari-sari (variety) store business and sells various items like soap, diapers, and canned goods. 

Rufina has applied for a loan and plans to use it to buy more items to sell such as rice and canned goods. She hopes to expand her sari-sari store in the future.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell such as rice and canned goods.

loans.name: Ekuba

texts.en:
Ekuba M. is a Wakye seller (cooked rice and beans). This dish is normally served with pepper sauce, macaroni, boiled eggs or salad. She is married and has three children. She has received junior high education. Her husband is a farmer. 

Her business is just two years old and she wants to grow it. She is requesting a loan to buy bags of rice, beans and other things so she can cook in larger quantities to meet the demand of her customers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ekuba plans to build a better structure to sell her food in.

At the time of the visit she had finished selling for the day and is showing how she dishes out the food.

loans.use: to buy bags of rice, beans and other items.

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Aba A. is married, has four children and makes a living by selling fish in the town of Elmina. Her husband is a farmer and Aba uses her income to help him support their family. She is applying for this loan to buy fresh fish and firewood. She plans to use the additional income made possible by this loan to pay for the education of her children.

loans.use: to buy fresh fish and firewood.

loans.name: Victoria  Afiewa Maame

texts.en: Victoria Afiewa Maame A. is a seamstress at Elmina. She has been sewing for the past four years. Demand for materials, lining and other cloth for sewing is increasing and therefore she needs a loan to acquire more of these items to supply her customers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to build a kiosk.

loans.use: to acquire more cloth, etc. to supply her customers.

loans.name: Bineta

texts.fr: Madame Bineta Diène habite dans la localité de Yoff. Elle est marié et  âgée de 61 ans. Depuis 10 ans elle s’active  dans la commercialisation de pâte d’arachide. Auparavant elle était artiste chanteuse et exerce régulièrement son activité a l’extérieur. Elle a choisi son activité par passion.  Elle aime bien voyager et est surtout intéressée  par la réalisation des profits. Madame Diène est sociétaire du guichet de Yoff à l’U-IMCEC depuis 2005. Elle a déjà remboursé 4 prêts antérieurs. Elle sollicite un crédit de 250 000 frs qui va servir pour l’achat de pâte d’arachide car elle prépare un voyage. Avec ce financement elle souhaite accroitre ses bénéfices pour ainsi améliorer la situation sociale de sa famille. Elle a 4 enfants dont l’âge  varie entre 15 et 40 ans. Son objectif est de les  soutenir  dans la gestion des dépenses liées à leurs études.
texts.en: Mrs. Bineta Diène lives in the Yoff area. She is married and 61 years old. For 10 years, she has been selling peanut butter. Before that, she was a singer. She regularly conducts her business outdoors. She chose her business because she likes it. She likes to travel and is especially interested in making profits. Mrs. Diène has been a member of the Yoff branch since January 2005. She has already repaid 4 loans. She seeks a loan of 250,000 fr which will be used to buy peanut butter, because she is planning a trip. With this loan, she hopes to grow her business to improve the social situation of her family. She has 4 children aged 15-40. Her goal is to support them in managing their finances related to their education.

loans.use: to buy peanut butter

loans.name: Sister Ama

texts.en: Sister Ama A. sells rice, oil, sugar, tomatoes, salted fish and other items at Elmina near Abreshia, a village in Cape Coast. She has been in this business for a long time and wishes to expand it. A loan from Kiva will help her to expand her business by purchasing more of the items she sells. She hopes to build a store from her sales one day.

loans.use: to buy more rice, oil, sugar, tomatoes, salted fish, etc.

loans.name: Merab

texts.en:
Merab R. is 55 years old. He is married and lives in the village of Dimi, Imereti Region. Merab lives with his big family consisting of himself, his wife, Nani, two sons (28 and 32 years old), two daughters-in-law and three grandchildren (two grandsons are two years old and the granddaughter is one year old). 

Merab is leading the agricultural activities of the family. In particular, they have three milk cows and sell cheese on the local market. Also the family owns vineyard (400 grape vines). Grapes are sold locally. 

With the requested credit Merab plans to construct a greenhouse where vegetables will be grown during the whole year. Harvested vegetables will be sold on the local market. This will significantly increase the income of the family. The profit will be reinvested in further development of the greenhouse.

loans.use: to purchase materials for greenhouse construction.

loans.name: Kajubwe Tukore Group A

texts.en:
38-year-old A. Edson, a happily married father of two has been working at his carpentry business in Omukashenyi-Kihihi for a decade now. He makes wooden chairs, doors, and tables. Since the beginning he has banked on hard work to make headway in his operations. He began his business with savings from his tea leaves sales business. He still does sell tea leaves though it's now more of a second fiddle business. 

Monthly he says his business profits amount to shillings 420,000 and he says with this loan, he is going to purchase more timber to make more chairs and other furniture to resell.

loans.use: to buy more timber to make furniture to resell.

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua E. is a producer of palm oil and palm kernel oil at Elmina. She is married to a farmer and has six dependents. The income she makes from her sales is used to help her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. 

E. will use the loan to purchase palm fruits and use the nuts to produce the kernel oil. With the new profits from her expanded business, E. plans to provide a meaningful education for her children.

loans.use: to purchase palm fruits and use the nuts for processing kernel oil.

loans.name: Abena

texts.en: Abena T. makes a living by selling fish and processing palm oil in the town of Elmina. She is married, has four children and has been in her current lines of work for about four years. She works hard to help her husband support their family, and has applied for this loan to buy more firewood and palm fruits. She plans to use the additional income made possible by this loan to educate her children.

loans.use: to buy firewood and palm fruits.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth A. makes a living by selling groundnut paste in her town of Elmina. She is married to a farmer, has four children and has been in her current line of work for six years. She works hard to help her husband pay their children's school fees and the family's utility bills. She will use this loan to buy groundnuts in bulk and hopes to use the additional profit she earns to buy a plot of land.

loans.use: to buy groundnuts in bulk.

loans.name: Aunty Aba Sarah

texts.en: Aunty Aba Sarah B. is a hairdresser at Elmina. She is married and has one child. Her husband is a teacher. Aba Sarah has been a hairdresser for three years. She helps her husband take care of the home. She needs a hair dryer. Her loan will be used to purchase a hair dyer and creams and hair products to use on customers' hair. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to build a better place.

loans.use: to purchase a hair dryer and creams and hair products.

loans.name: Adjoa Mansah Gladys

texts.en: Adjoa Mansah Gladys A. is a widow and has six dependents. Gladys sells cloth, bags, etc. at Elmina by moving around the locality, which she has done for 10 years.  She will use the loan to purchase cloth, bags and shoes to expand her business. With the new profits from her expanded business, Gladys plans to build a shop.

loans.use: to purchase cloth, bags and shoes.

loans.name: Lemomo

texts.en:
Lemomo K. is a 41-year-old man who is married to Lepesony and together they have three children aged 14, 10 and eight years. He is in the livestock trade business. He buys cows and bulls when still young and rears them, then he resells them at a profit. He has been in this business for the last eight years and he gets a profit of Kenya shillings 21,000. His business is in the busy Kitengela market.

Lemomo joined KADET the other day, after introductions by another client, and he has applied for his first loan which he will use to buy more livestock. He hopes to use the anticipated profits to establish a shop where he can sell roasted meat to his clients.

He has dreams of buying a big ranch where he can sell livestock and meat wholesale. He describes himself as hard-working and focused.

loans.use: To buy more livestock.

loans.name: Adjoa Mama Gladys

texts.en: Adjoa Mama Gladys M. sells cooked "banku" (fermented corn dough), meat and soft drinks at Elmina. She is married to a teacher and together they live with their three children.  She is responsible for assisting her husband to pay household expenses. Her loan will be used to buy more crates of soft drinks for sale. She hopes to plough back her profit into her business.

loans.use: to buy more crates of soft drinks for sale.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence E. makes both palm oil and palm kernel oil at Elmina. Florence is married and has six dependents. Her husband is a farmer. She has been producing these oils for three years. She helps her husband to take care of the home. Her loan will be used to buy additional palm fruits to process for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her children.

loans.use: to buy additional palm fruits to process for sale.

loans.name: Safina

texts.en: Safina N. lives in the Kyebando neighborhood of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has two children, both of whom are in school. For the past year she has made a living by selling clothes. She works six days a week, selling her products by going door to door. She is applying for a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more bales of second clothes. Her main challenges are transportation and theft, but she hopes to see her business grow large and become an importer. She owns her home, but it does not have electricity or piped-in water.  Her biggest monthly expenses are food, school fees and medicines.

loans.use: to buy bales of second-hand clothes to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Zebikhon

texts.ru: Исмоилова Зебихон проживает в районе Вахдат. Ей 40 лет. Она замужем, имеет 4 детей. Её муж занимается строительными работами по найму. Сама Зебихон более 10 лет занимается животноводством. Она разводит крупнорогатый скот у себя дома. В основном она откармливает и продает скот. Кредит берет для закупа скота.
texts.en: Zebikhon I. lives in Vahdat. She is 40 years old, married, and has four children. Her husband is a day laborer working in construction.  Zebikhon has been working in animal husbandry for more than ten years. She raises cattle at home. She primarily fattens and sells cattle. She is taking out a loan to buy cattle.

loans.use: to buy cattle

loans.name: Moustapha Aliou

texts.fr: Monsieur Moustapha Aliou S. est un jeune yoffois de 24 ans qui s’active dans la prestation de services  dans le domaine de la photographie et du reportage dans les cérémonies. Il a choisi cette occupation par passion et aussi a cause de l’aspect  lucratif et rentable de l’activité. Monsieur S. est un célibataire ambitieux qui souhaite réorganiser son activité  pour bien gérer  son avenir futur. Il est sociétaire du guichet de Yoff depuis octobre 2010. Il sollicite un crédit de 500 000 frs prévu pour l’achat d’un caméra et d’une imprimante dans le but de mieux développer son activité de prestation de services. Ce financement lui permettra d’aménager  le studio dont il dispose  afin de pouvoir mieux rentabiliser son activité.
texts.en: Mr. Moustapha Aliou S. is a young 24-year-old man from Yoff who provides photography and reporting services in ceremonies. He chose this occupation because he likes it and also because of its lucrative and profitable aspect. Mr. S. is an ambitious single man who wishes to reorganize his business in order to better manage his future. He has been a member of the Yoff branch since January 2010. He seeks a loan of 500,000 fr intended to buy a video camera and printer in the goal of better developing his business. This loan will allow him to equip the studio he has at his disposal in order to make his business more profitable.

loans.use: to buy a video camera and printer

loans.name: Avtandil

texts.en:
Avtandil B. lives in the village of Siktarva in the Imereti Region. He is 56 years old and married. Avtandil lives with his family: his wife Tinatin, his 82-year-old mother, his 19-year-old son and his 15-year-old daughter. 

The only source of income for the family comes from agriculture. They own two greenhouses covering a total area of 144 sq meters. Cucumbers, tomatoes and greens are grown in the greenhouse. It is productive during the whole year. Harvested vegetables and greens are sold locally. Along with the greenhouse, the family owns 70 beehives with bee colonies. Two times a year, Avtandil gets honey from the hives and sells it locally. He also sells bee colonies. 

Because of unfavorable weather conditions, Avtandil lost 30 beehives and bees last season. It was a big loss for the family business. With the requested loan, Avtandil will purchase an additional 20 beehives and bee colonies and will partially restore the old productivity of his bee-keeping farm. It will positively influence the income of the family. 

The earned profit will be used for financing the high school expenses of his son.

loans.use: to purchase beehives and bee colonies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy pots, plastic plates, and bowls for resale

loans.name: Karen

texts.en: Karen B. and his family have engaged in animal breeding and bee keeping since 2004. Karen raises sheep, cows and calves, and also has five bee families. With his farming income Karen meets his family’s needs and increases his farming livestock. To increase his family’s profit, Karen asks for a 1.000.000 AMD loan to buy a mowing machine, which will allow him to work for hire on neighboring fields. Karen is 27 years old and lives in Geghamavan village, Gegharkunik marz, with his parents, his wife and two children.

loans.use: To buy a mowing machine

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 54-year-old single woman living with her parents and one sibling. She is from Lebanon. She has owned a mini market since 1990. She sells perishable and non-perishable goods and has a deep understanding of local consumer needs. She obtained her first Kiva loan and has been a very punctual client. She has actually repaid her loan in full several months earlier. Today, she is requesting to borrow $2,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to increase her store’s inventory. She has high hopes for the future of her business and always tends to be in the requisition of her customers.

loans.use: to increase her store’s inventory

loans.name: Adolé

texts.fr: Agée de 40ans, Mme Adolé est mère de 03 enfants. Son mari est employé au port de Lomé. Elle a débuté son activité (vente de sucre riz et huile végétale) en 1991 et s’y donne avec joie. Elle s’approvisionne à Lomé et revend de façon ambulante à Adamavo, Kagomé et Adakpamé. C’est une fidele cliente de notre institution(WAGES) qui est à son treizième prêt. Elle sollicite ce montant pour acheter 03 sacs de sucre,02 sacs de riz et 02 bidons d’huile pour revendre à la population de Lomé et ses environs afin d’avoir de profit pour avoir tout d’abord sa boutique pour installer son étalage, s’assurer d’un avenir radieux de ses enfants et aider son mari dans les taches ménagères
texts.en:
Mme Adolé, 40, is the mother of three children. Her husband has a job at the port of Lomé. She began her little business selling sugar, rice, and vegetable oil, in 1991 and does this work with joy. She buys her supplies in Lomé and sells her wares on foot in Adamavo, Kagomé, and Adakpamé. 

She is a loyal client of our firm (WAGES) and is on her thirteenth loan. She is asking for this sum to buy three sacks of sugar, two sacks of rice, and two jerrycans of oil to sell to the population of Lomé and surrounding areas so that she can make enough profit to be able to set herself up in a little shop with shelving, ensure a bright future for her children, and help her husband with the family chores.

loans.use: to buy sugar, rice, and vegetable oil.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 45-year-old Lebanese married man living with his wife and four school-age children. He has proven to be a successful entrepreneur with his computer and amusement shop. He has owned and run this business for more than two years. He has a good number of customers visiting his shop to spend an enjoying time playing with different games. In parallel, he works as a cleaning agent in his hometown’s municipality. This man works hard to satisfy his family needs and to be able to pay for his children schooling. With his loan of $800 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l, he will improve his business by purchasing sweets, snacks and drinks. He is positive about his business prospects and plans to further expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase sweets, snacks and drinks

loans.name: Kajubwe Tukore Group B

texts.en: Samuel B., 62, right with hand raised, is an agriculturist from Kajubwe in Kihihi District. He grows and sells tea leaves. The father of 7, he also plants and sells coffee. He has been in this business for the past 20 years and he says he got start up capital from a modest coffee sales business.  He says this business generates him profits of shillings 700,000 UGX a month and with this loan he is going to purchase more high-grade manure for his tea gardens.

loans.use: to purchase more high-grade manure for use in his tea gardens

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase additional products

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 53-year-old married woman living with her husband and one child. She is from Lebanon. She sells a wide range of Lebanese food and products from her home to customers from her community. She has been working hard to support her family in cooperation with her husband who works in a local food company.

Today, she is requesting to borrow $1,500 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase milk in order to produce its delicious derivatives such as white cheese, yogurt, etc.  In the future, she would like to rent out a space to sell her merchandise, as well as to sell popular homemade food products. This will be her second Kiva loan.

loans.use: to purchase milk to make her products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 50-year-old married woman from Lebanon. She is living with her husband and three young children who are still attending school. She has owned a female beauty salon since 1995. Her husband has owned a small shop since 2001 where he sells different electrical equipment and machinery. They cooperate together to reach the required financial goal in order to make their family live in appropriate conditions.  She has taken her first Kiva loan and has been a good client with prompt payments. 

Today, she is requesting to borrow $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase beauty products and related accessories. She is very positive and hoping to increase her business level.

loans.use: to purchase beauty products and related accessories

loans.name: Madina

texts.en: Madina N. lives in the Mengo Mackay neighborhood of the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has one child in school. Madina has a business selling clothes. She has been in this business for three years, and works 7 days out of every week. Madina sells her products at the market, wholesale and retail. Madina has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more bales of second-hand clothes.The main business challenges for Madina are transportation and seasonality. Her goal for her business is to see it grow big and start importing clothes. Madina lives in a home that she owns with access to electricity but not to piped water. Her major monthly expenses are food, school fees, and medication

loans.use: To buy more bales of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Sogbadji

texts.fr: A 27 ans et mariée à un chaudronnier, Mme E. mère d un enfant est revendeuse de bijoux plaqué or à Adakpamé, (une ville de Lomé) après achat au grand marche de Lomé. Elle sollicite ce prêt pour se lancer dans la vente des produits de premières  nécessités (riz, tomates en conserve, sucre, huile végétale) dû à la mévente rencontrée dans le commerce des bijoux. Elle veut se battre dans son couple pour aider son mari financièrement
texts.en: At age 27 and married to a boiler-maker, Mrs. E. is the mother of one child and has been selling gold-plated jewelry in Adakpamé (a neighborhood of Lomé) after buying her wares at the Grand Market of Lomé. She is requesting this loan to open up a little shop selling everyday necessities (rice, tinned tomatoes, sugar, vegetable oil) since she encountered a slowdown in jewelry sales. She wants to pull her weight in the couple to help her husband financially.

loans.use: to buy foodstuffs for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy new hairdressing tools and equipment

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase farm supplies.

loans.name: Mashenya Kwetungura Group

texts.en: Silver, 47, on left, has been in the agricultural business for the past three years in Kihihi. The happily married father of six grows and sells tea leaves. This business was one he started due to the high demand for tea leaves in Western Uganda. Silver, like many other people in the west of Uganda, grew up in a family with a farming legacy. It was only natural that, with time, he would start bearing a hand in this business. Silver also has a banana plantation where he harvests bananas to sell. This has helped him increase his income. He says his business earnings are Uganda shillings 100,000 a week and, with this loan, he will purchase fertilizer for use in his farming gardens.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer for his tea gardens

loans.name: Zurab

texts.en:
Zurab E. is a 57-year-old farmer from village Etseri, West Georgia. He is married and lives with his wife Tamara, 85-year-old mother and 26-year-old son. Zurab heads a poultry farm. He started it five years ago. He raises on his farm up to 1,000 chickens and sells them to the wholesalers. Also seasonally, he sells grapes harvested in his family’s vineyard (500 wine trees). Tamara is actively involved in family farming activities. Their average monthly income is 800 Laris. Their son has his own small business and earns on average 400 Laris per month. 

The requested loan will be used to purchase of maize for feeding the chickens. The loan will help him to purchase a big amount of the corn at a wholesale price, which will reduce his expenses for feeding the chickens, resulting in increased profit. 

With the increase in profit, Zurab and Tamara will renovate their house and purchase some household items, which will improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase maize for his chickens

loans.name: Edith  W.

texts.en: Edith N. is 26 years old, married and has one child. Her husband makes a living by driving a vehicle while Edith works as a poultry farmer. She has been in this line of work for three years and earns 18,000 Kenya shillings a month. She joined KADET a while back and is currently applying for her third loan, which she will use to buy a cow for milking. She plans to combine the additional income made possible by this loan with the savings she has accumulated at KADET to buy a second cow. Eventually, she hopes to own four cows, a larger poultry flock and a piece of land she can farm.

loans.use: To buy a cow to milk.

loans.name: Lampeshua Ole

texts.en: Lampeshua Ole M. is 46 years old, married and has three children, two of whom are in school. For the last eight years, he has made a living by growing wheat and by raising sheep and goats. He learned about KADET LTD through our staff, has successfully repaid his first loan and is applying for a second loan, for KES. 50,000, to prepare his land for planting and to buy sheep and goats to raise and later sell for a profit. He plans to use the additional income made possible by this loan to educate his children. His long-term goal is to continue expanding his business.

loans.use: to prepare his land for planting and buy sheep and goats to raise and sell.

loans.name: Lucy N.

texts.en:
Lucy Njamb, a 31- year-old married mother of two children aged three and six years, operates a mobile money transfer service and sells CDs and DVDs in her retail shop. In business since 2007, she earns a monthly profit of Kenya shillings 12,000.

Lucy joined KADET just the other day and is now applying for her first loan to purchase more CDs and DVDs for her shop and to use as additional capital for the money transfer (M-pesa) business. The anticipated profits will be used to make her life more comfortable.

In the future she hopes to expand her M-pesa business and be a major supplier of DVDs and CDs.

loans.use: to buy more CDs and DVDs for resale and have additional capital for her  M-pesa business.

loans.name: Eliud Mwangi

texts.en:
Eliud Mwangi is 36 years old and married to Ann Waitura, who contributes to the family income. Eliud has been a dairy farmer for three years and earns a monthly income of about 13,000 Kenya shillings. This will be his first loan from KADET LTD with which he will buy animal feed, expand his animal-feeding area and invest in tea farming.

Eliud hopes to eventually own a bigger dairy farm and distribute milk to the nearby community.

loans.use: to buy animal feed, expand his animal-feeding area and invest in tea farming.

loans.name: Adu

texts.en:
Adu H. is married and has eight children. As a Muslim, Adu was reluctant to join GHAPE in the past for fear of rejection, but he was pleasantly surprised by the warm reception other members gave him. He joined the program in January 2010 and received his first loan February 2010 which he used to buy more items for his grocery store. Given the size of his immediate family and the many extended family members who rely on him, Adu faces considerable difficulty in meeting their needs. He has been a victim of bush fires several times that destroyed some of his crops. These fires come about as a result of the fact that many people rear cattle in his community and so burn the bushes in the dry season to allow fresh grass to sprout for the cattle.

With this new loan, Adu plans to increase the size of his grocery store to meet community needs. He will use the additional profits arising from the loan to pay school fees for his children and provide food, clothing and medication for his immediate and extended family members.

About GHAPE

The Grounded and Holistic Approach for Peoples’ Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: to buy and sell groceries.

location.town: Acha, Momo Division, North West Region

loans.name: William

texts.en:
William M., a 36-year-old married father of four children aged 12, 14, 16 and 9 years, has been selling shoes in the Kangemi area for the last 13 years, earning a monthly income of Kenya shillings 24,000.

William is now applying for his second loan from KADET with which he plans to purchase more shoes for resale. He hopes to use the anticipated extra income to pay school fees for his children. His dream is to be a supplier of shoes to other retail shoe dealers.

loans.use: to buy more shoes for resale.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes N. lives in the Kamwokya neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has four children, one of whom is in school.  

Agnes lives in a home that she rents. She has access to electricity but not to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food, school fees and medication.   

Agnes runs a pub. She has been in this business for three years and she works seven days out of every week. Agnes sells her products by means of retail. 

Agnes has requested a loan of 500,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more crates of beer and jerry cans of local gin. 

The main business challenges for Agnes include defaulters and the increasing price of beer.  

Her goals are to see her business grow big, to own a fully stocked pub and also to build her own house.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer and jerry cans of local gin.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is 37 years old and married to Raphael, who is a businessman in Ndarachi village in Thika town. 

She has a motorcycle transport business that she has employed someone to run since she is employed. She has four children and has been in the transport business for a period of six years with an income of 19,600 KES a month.

This is her first loan from KADET Ltd., and she wants to use the loan to buy a piece of land with some other group members as they decided to pool the resources together so that they can buy the land. Once they have bought the land they will subdivide it amongst themselves so that each members can do as they please with their specific portion. 

She hopes to own rental houses and give her children quality education.

loans.use: to buy a piece of land as a group.

loans.name: Protea Group

texts.en:
Willium S., who is in his early 30s, is married and has two children who are at school. For two years now, he has been making traditional baskets that he sells from door to door. He works from 7:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit.

This will be Willium's fourth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loans to buy material for making baskets and has paid back his loans successfully.  

He has made a good number of baskets, and he hopes for a loan to travel to Nairobi, Kenya, to sell his baskets. 

His dream is to one day be able to make very many baskets and even to employee some helpers.

Willium will share this loan with his loan group, "Protea," which has a total of 15 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

In the picture, Willium is first on the left in a white shirt.

loans.use: To travel and sell  baskets at Nairobi, Kenya.

loans.name: Kum Nicholas

texts.en:
Kum Nicholas K. is 61 years old. He is a polygamist and has eight children, three of whom are below the age of 15. Given the low level of education of his older children, most of them are unemployed, requiring them to rely on their parents. He also faces a lot of food shortages in his home because of his large family size. 

Given this loan, he plans to buy more yam seeds and fertilizers, and also to expand his cassava farm. He is an old and experienced farmer and this loan will go a long way to boost the quality and quantity of his harvest. The size of his family is also an added advantage as they will provide the needed labor in the farm. The harvest will be sold in local market to provide other commodities to the family that they cannot produce and also to provide a means for the children to take a step further in education. 

About GHAPE 
The Grounded and Holistic Approach for People s’ Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: to buy more yam seeds and fertilizers and to expand his cassava farm.

loans.name: Winfred

texts.en:
Winfred K. is a 37-year-old single lady who is the mother of two children. She runs a grocery stall at Zambezi market in Limuru town. 

This is her primary business, which she has been doing for the last four years.

This is her fourth loan from KADET Ltd., and she intends to use it to pay school fees for her children. 

Winfred hopes to educate her children and to grow her business.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Mema Group

texts.en:
Clement M., who is in his late 40's, is a married father of four children, all of whom are still in school. He has been running a general store for eight years now. Working from 6:00 am to 10:00 pm daily, he is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Clement's fifth Motisha loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. A Motisha loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania allowing borrowers with good credit ratings to repay their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term has ended. Clement used the previous loans, all since repaid, to sell fruits and vegetables, buy a cow for milk sales, and increase shop stock. He now hopes for a loan to increase his shop inventory. His dream is to one day start selling cement.

Clement will share his loan with his loan group "Mema," which has a total of seven members. The group members will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

In the picture, Clement is at the back with a dark red shirt.

loans.use: to Increase shop inventory.

loans.name: Elizabeth Waithira

texts.en:
The mother of two children aged 16 and 14 years, Elizabeth is 40 years old and married to David, who contributes to the family income. Elizabeth has been running her grocery shop for about three years, earning approximately 9,000 Kenya shillings a month.

Introduced to KADET LTD by a group member, she is requesting her first loan to buy stock of fruits, green vegetables and cereals. Elizabeth hopes to eventually own a permanent house, have a retail shop, and improve the living standard of her family.

loans.use: to add stocks of fruits, green vegetables and cereals.

loans.name: Calfonia Group

texts.en:
Judith S., who is in her early 20s, is single.  She has been running a cafeteria for three years now. She works from 6:00 am to 5:00 pm daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be Judith's first motisha loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  A Motisha loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term has ended. She hopes for a loan to buy herself a fridge for her cafe.  Her dream is to one day buy land.

Judith will share this loan with her loan group "Calfonia", which has a total of eight members.  The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

In the picture, Judith is second from left in the back row.

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator.

loans.name: Luz Divina Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Luz Divina inicia su ciclo número 40 con 11 socias, las que se dedican a la venta de panes, productos de belleza, preparación de comidas, reparación de zapatos y venta de alimentos.
Celsa es la Presidenta del Banco Comunal, es casada, tiene 50 años y 2 hijos de 27 y 24 años de edad. Celsa se dedica la siembra de paltos. Celsa es de profesión Técnico en enfermería trabaja en el Hospital de Apoyo de Ayacucho y también tiene un plantación de paltos de la variedad forte y linda en la provincia de Huanta. Vende a los acopiadores en su chacra. Ella solicita un préstamo para invertir en la compra de fertizantes y remedios para su plantación de paltos.
Celsa está en FINCA Perú hace 12 años, ingresó por la invitación de una socia, le gusta por los créditos que le dan a base de confianza, por los gratos momentos que pasa con sus compañeras de banco. Fue 2 veces Presidenta de su Banco Comunal y fue banco modelo. Gracias a FINCA Perú, educó a sus hijos y ahora son profesionales. Su sueño es poder comercializar sus paltos en forma directa y ya no vender a través de los acopiadores.
texts.en:
The communal bank named "Divine Light" has started its 40th loan cycle with their 11 members. They sell breads, beauty products, prepared foods, shoe repair services, and food.

Celsa is the president of the communal bank. She is married, 50 years old, and she has 2 children, aged 27 and 24. Celsa cultivates avocadoes. Celsa's profession is nursing technology and she works in the Apoyo Hospital in Ayacucho. She also has a plantation of avocadoes of a strong and beautiful variety in the province of Huanta. She sells to the distributors in the area. She requests a loan to invest in the purchase of fertilizers and pesticides for her avocado plantation. Celsa has been part of Finca Peru (Kiva Field Partner) for 12 years. She joined following an invitation from a member. She enjoys it because the loans are granted based on trustworthiness and for the glad times she passes with her colleagues of the bank. She has been the president of the group twice before and it was a model bank. Thanks to Finca Peru she was able to send her kids to school and today they have careers. Her dream is to be able to sell her avocadoes directly and not to have to sell through distributors.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and pesticides for her avocado plantation.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce M., a resident of the Mulago neighborhood in Kampala, Uganda, is married and has five children, one of whom is in school. She also takes care of elderly parents. Joyce has operated a wholesale milk-selling business from home for three years, working seven days each week.

Joyce has requested a loan of 500000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more jerycans of milk. The main business challenges she faces include defaulters and increasing milk prices. Her goals are to expand her business and purchase her own milk cooler.

Joyce lives in a home that she rents which has electricity but no piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food, school fees and utility bills.

loans.use: to buy more jerycans of milk.

loans.name: Henry K.

texts.en:
Henry K., a 41-year-old-man separated from his wife but taking care of their two children aged 14 and 16 years, operates a successful construction business in Kinoo. An old client of KADET, Henry is requesting his seventh loan, having repaid his previous loans. He plans to use it to purchase more tools for his business and will put the anticipated increased profits toward his children's education.

Henry's goals are to build his own house and be the area's best contractor.

loans.use: to purchase construction tools for his business.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Stephen N. is 53 years old and the father of six children. His wife is a housewife. Two of his daughters, Eunice (13years old) and Suzan (15 years old), are in school.

Stephen has been running his dairy business for 21 years. This will be his fourth loan from KADET LTD, and he intends to use it to buy a dairy cow so as to increase milk production and buy more cattle feed.

Stephen hopes to educate his children and improve his business.

loans.use: to educate his children and improve his dairy business.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel Y. is a 38 year single man who sells secondhand shoes in the Gikomba open air market. He has been in business for the last six years, and he gets a monthly income of 8,000 KES.

Emmanuel applied for his first loan with KADET after he joined recently. He plans to use the amount to buy two more bales of shoes so as to increase his stock. He plans to use the anticipated profits in his business to expand.

In the future Emmanuel hopes to partner with a shoe company in Kenya known as BATA so that he can be the supplier of their new shoes to other retailers.

loans.use: To buy two more bales of shoes for resale.

loans.name: Ana Milena

texts.es: Ana Milena de 29 años vive con su cónyuge y su hijo de 7 años en Mesolandia, barrio ubicado en el municipio de Malambo;  allí se dedica a la venta de carnes y bebidas frías como cerveza y gaseosas,  negocio que inició hace 4 años cuando vendía por encargos a sus vecinos, pero gradualmente fue evolucionando su capital y con ello compró una nevera para refrigerar y conservar sus productos, así empezó a  incrementar sus ventas porque agregó a su negocio el mercado de las tiendas que hoy aun le compran. Todos estos logros los ha conseguido con su esfuerzo y con los 3 financiamientos que ha tenido  con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo; su credikiva es el cuarto financiamiento con el cual comprará canastas de cervezas, hará adecuaciones locativas y comprará silletería y otros enseres, porque  ella cuenta que ahora tiene 2 negocios  y que ha hecho mejoras locativas solo a uno de ellos, sus negocios están ubicados en dos sitios diferentes,  pero uno de ellos  funciona solamente  los fines de semana y  que ella además genera otros ingresos como ayudante de una panadería. Su negocio gozan de una buena presentación y reputación y ahora  su sueño se concentra en tener una panadería,  para que su esposo aplique sus conocimientos y su vocación  al servicio de los ingresos familiares y este es obviamente su mayor desafío.
texts.en: Ana Milena is 29 years old and she lives with her common-law husband and their 7-year old son in Mesolandia. It is a district located in the municipality of Malambo. She sells meats and cold drinks such as beer and soft drinks. She started her business 4 years ago and she only sold by taking orders from her neighbors. But her capital funds gradually increased and with it she purchased a freezer to keep and conserve her products. Her sales increased when she joined her business to the market and the stores still buy from her. All of these achievements have been realized with her efforts and with the help of 3 loans she has had from Fundacion Mario Santo Domingo (Kiva Field Partner). Her Kiva loan will be her fourth and with it she will purchase boxes of beer, she will condition her store, and she will purchase a transportation harness and other equipment. She now has 2 businesses and she has reconditioned only one of them. Her businesses are located in two different locations but one of them only operates on the weekends. She earns an additional source of income by working as a helper at a bakery. Her business enjoys a good presentation and reputation and today her dream is to have a bakery. Her husband will be able to employ his knowledge and to work in his vocation to earn an income for the family. This is obviously her greatest goal.

loans.use: to purchase cases of beer, recondition her business, and to purchase tools.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase firewood for firing bricks.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence N. is 30 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala central region of Uganda. She is single and has one child, who is not currently in school. Florence has a salon business, which she has run for seven years.
To help expand her business, Florence has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more hair braids for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Florence hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, she hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more hair braids for resale.

loans.name: Sophie

texts.en:
Sophie N. lives in the Makerere neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has four children, one of whom is in school. She also takes care of her elderly parents. Sophie lives in a home that she rents. She has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food, school fees and utility bills.

Sophie operates a restaurant. She has been in this business for three years, and she works seven days a week. She also generates additional income by selling sodas at the market. The main business challenges for Sophie include defaulters and the increasing price of food.

Sophie has requested a loan of 500,000 KES from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of bananas, beef, sweet and Irish potatoes, and rice. Her goals for her business are to see it grow bigger and own a fully stocked restaurant.

loans.use: to buy more bunches of bananas, beef, sweet and Irish potatoes, and rice.

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary is 48 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala central region of Uganda. She is married and has two children, one of whom is currently in school. Rosemary has a small retail shop business, which she has run for less than one year.         
To help expand her business, Rosemary has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more essential commodities, such as sugar, for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Rosemary hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, she hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more essential commodities, such as sugar, for resale.

loans.name: Juan Jorge

texts.es:
Juan de 41 años es soltero, vive en casa de su madre, cuenta con todos los servicios (agua, luz y desagüe), ubicado en la parte urbana de Olmos .  La cual se caracteriza por su actividad agrícola y ganadera.

La actividad que desarrolla Juan es de chofer de transporte público, desde algún tiempo, su ruta es desde Olmos a sus distintos caserios y viseversa.  Cuenta también con una moto lineal que le permite ir con mayor rapidez a sus  tierras donde cultiva limón, estas actividades le permiten tener mayores ingresos para poder solventar sus gastos en la casa y tener un mejor nivel de vida.

Al observar Juan que sus negocios son prósperos a visto la posibilidad de pedir un préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa de 500 nuevos soles para comprar fertilizantes que mejoren la calidad de sus productos y también brindar mantenimiento a sus tierras de cultivo.  Al obtener un producto de calidad, va a poder pedir mejor precio a los comerciantes que le compran limón y por lo mismo mejorará progresivamente su calidad de vida y podrá seguir ayudando a su madre en lo que sea necesario.

Juan es una persona muy trabajadora, responsable y buen hijo por ayudar a su madre a que no le haga falta nada.
texts.en:
Juan is 41 years old, single, and he lives in his mother's house. It is equipped with all the services (water, electricity, and sewage) and it is located in the urban region of Olmos. It is known for its agricultural and farming activities.

Juan's business has been public transportation for some time. His route is from Olmos to the different communities and vice versa. He also has a motorcycle that allows him to reach his farm land quicker. There he cultivates lemons. These activities help him have a greater income to cover the household expenses and to have a better quality of life.

When Juan saw that his businesses have prospered he took an opportunity to request a loan from Edpyme Alternativa (Kiva Field Partner) in the amount of 500 nuevos soles. He will purchase fertilizers to improve the quality of his products and he will also provide maintenance care to his farm land. When he obtains a quality product he will be able to ask a better price from the merchants who purchase the lemon. And so this will progressively improve the quality of his life and he will continue to help him other in whatever is needed. 

Juan is a very hard working person who is responsible and a good son for ensuring that his mother not want for anything.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and to maintain his farm land.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles M. is 35 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala central region of Uganda. He is married and has two children, both of whom are currently in school. Charles has a furniture-making shop business, which he has run for seven years.
To help expand his business, Charles has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more timber for making chairs. With the help of his loan from BRAC, Charles hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children. In the future, he hopes to expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase more timber for making chairs.

loans.name: Ronald

texts.en:
Ronald S. is 36 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala central region of Uganda. He is married and has two children, both of whom are currently in school. Ronald has a butcher shop business, which he has run for six years. He also has a second business running a restaurant.
To help expand his business, Ronald has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more meat for resale. With the help of his loan from BRAC, Ronald hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children. In the future, he hopes to expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase more meat for resale.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. J. is a married lady who has four children aged between twelve and twenty-three years old. She describes herself as God-fearing and customer-friendly.

Mary sells fish to local people. She has been in this business for ten years now. Her business is located along the roadside in Kisumu, the region of Kenya that includes the famous Lake Victoria and is well known for production of tilapia fish. She works very hard to keep her business doing well.

Mary says that her business is profitable, but her major challenge is a lack of refrigeration facilities to keep the fish fresh longer. She is using her loan of 60,000 KES to buy a freezer to store her fish. Mary hopes to be a wholesaler in future. She also sees herself owning fish ponds in which she will raise fish to sell.

loans.use: to buy a freezer to store her fish.

loans.name: Henry

texts.en:
Henry N. is 45 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala central region of Uganda. He is married and has three children, all of whom are currently in school. Henry has a business making bricks, which he has run for five years. He also has a second business selling phone airtime.
To help expand his business, Henry has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase firewood for firing bricks, which he will then sell. With the help of his loan from BRAC, Henry hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children. In the future, he hopes to expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase firewood for firing bricks.

loans.name: Nakato

texts.en:
Nakato D. is 48 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala central region of Uganda. She is married and has eight children, one of whom is currently in school. Nakato has a business selling sand and soil for housebuilding, and she has run this business for four years.
To help expand her business, Nakato has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more sand and soil (for building houses) for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Nakato hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, she hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more sand and soil for resale.

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick M. M. is 33 years old, married and has three children. While he was previously employed, for the past six years he has operated a retail shop. Additionally, he employs one person.

Through the loans from Faulu Kenya, Patrick has grown his business. He has now requested 90,000 KES to buy sugar, rice, cooking fat and maize flour. He hopes to expand his business into wholesale marketing in the future.

loans.use: To buy sugar, rice, cooking fat and maize flour

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane N. is 47 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala central region of Uganda. She is widowed and has eight children, four of whom are currently in school. Jane has a salon business, which she has run for two years. She also has a second business selling sugar cane.
To help expand her business, Jane has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase hair braids for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Jane hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. In the future, she hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase hair braids for resale.

loans.name: Fatumah

texts.en:
Fatumah N. is 32 years old and lives in the town of Makindye in the Kampala central region of Uganda. She is married and has four children, three of whom are currently in school. Fatumah has a business selling clothes, which she has run for two years.
To help expand her business, Fatumah has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more clothes for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Fatumah hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, she hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes for resale.

loans.name: Luis Fernando

texts.es:
Luis es un hombre soltero de 29 años de edad, vive en casa de sus padres, es propia y cuenta con todos los servicio ( agua, luz y desagüe) en el distrito de José Leonardo Ortiz, que pertenece a la provincia de Chiclayo.  Los pobladores de éste distrito se dedican principalmente al comercio y turismo.
Luis  es propietario de juegos infantiles (camas elásticas para que los niños salten), esta labor lo realiza desde hace algunos años en el parque principal de ese distrito, para quel os niños puedan acceder al juego tienen que pagar 1.00 un nuevo sol, éste negocio en la actualidad se ha ido incrementando especialmente los fines de semana y en días festivos.  Al tener mayores ingresos de su negocio el puede   solventar sus gastos y necesidades.
El crédito que ha solicitado a Edpyme Alternativa es de 2000 nuevos soles y su destino será para comprar otros juegos para niños innovadores para que tenga más acogida su negocio y seguirá prosperando, tratando de mejorar la calidad de vida de él y la de sus padres.
Luis es un hombre muy responsable y conocido en el medio por ser trabajador  y buen hijo al estar pendiente de lo que necesitan sus padres.
texts.en:
Luis is a single man, 29 years old, and he lives in his parents' house. It is his own house and it is equipped with all the services (water, electricity and sewage). It is located in the district of Jose Leonardo Ortiz, in the province of Chiclayo. The population of this district are primarily involved in commerce and tourism. 

Luis is the owner of a children's game park (trampolines for kids to jump). He has had this business for a few years at the principal park of the district. The kids who want to access the part need to pay 1 neuvo sol. Business has been increasing especially during the weekends and on holidays. With an increase in income he is able to cover his expenses and provide for his needs.

The loan which he requests from Edpyme Alternativa (Kiva Field Partner) is in the amount of 2000 nuevos soles and it will be used to purchase other and innovative children's games to bring more attention to the business. he will continue to prosper and he will continue to improve his quality of life and that of his parents. 

Luis is a very responsible person and known in his line of business to be a hard worker and a good son for providing his parent with what they need.

loans.use: to purchase new game park attractions.

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret M. is 38 years old and lives in the town of Makindye in the Kampala central region of Uganda. She is single and has four children, three of whom are currently in school. Margret has a bar, which she has run for five years. She also has a second business running a poultry firm.
To help expand her business, Margret has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more sodas and beer for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Margret hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, she hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more sodas and beer for resale.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel N. M. is fifty-three years old and married to a businesswoman. They have four children aged between eighteen and twenty-five years old. They live in Kakamega, a rich agricultural area in Kenya commonly known as the sugar-belt region because of its production of sugarcane. Samuel and his wife hope to give their children a good education up to the university level. He describes himself as a hardworking and visionary man.

Samuel operates a matatu (a minibus) which he uses to provide transport on the Kakamega-Kisumu route. He has been in business for the last three years and has managed to provide employment for two people. He says that while this business is profitable, his major challenge is competition; there are many people offering the same service as his, reducing the amount of profit he can make per day. Additionally, the poor roads in Kakamega become almost impassable during the cold season. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well.

Samuel is using this loan of 40,000 KES to buy new tires for his matatu so as to enable him to improve his business. He hopes to buy more transport vehicles in the future to service different routes. He also sees himself owning a plot of land where he will build a house for his family.

loans.use: to buy new tires for his matatu.

loans.name: Rosette

texts.en:
Rosette M. is 36 years old and lives in the town of Makindye in the Kampala central region of Uganda. She is married and has five children, four of whom are currently in school. Rosette has a stationery shop business, which she has run for five years.
To help expand her business, Rosette has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more printing paper for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Rosette hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, she hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more printing paper for resale.

loans.name: Pulacayo Group

texts.es:
El banco de emprendimiento "PULACAYO" se encuentra en su segundo ciclo , el cual esta conformado por personas responsables y trabajadoras, este Banco de Emprendimiento esta representado por las siguientes socias: Presidenta la señora Margarita quien es separada, tiene 3 hijos pequeños a quienes los mantiene sola, su actividad económica es la venta de frutas de forma ambulante, su crédito esta destinado para la compra de frutas por temporada como manzana, naranja, mandarina y piña y así de esta manera incrementar capital de trabajo, la Sra. margarita trabaja desde tempranas horas de la mañana para abastecerse de frutas y después ir vendiendo barrio por barrio, su deseo es el ver a sus hijos profesionales y ser personas de bien, esta profundamente agradecida por la oportunidad que le brindan.
Todas las socias son personas responsables y trabajadoras que están agradecidas con la institución por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en:
The communal bank named "Pulacayo" is on their second loan cycle. It is made up of responsible and hard working members. This communal bank is represented by the following member: the president of the group, Margarita. She is separated and she has 3 young children whom she is raising alone. Her business is to sells fruit itinerantly. her loan will be used to purchase seasonal fruit, such as apples, oranges, mandarins, and pineapples. this will help her increase her working capital. Margarita works from the early hours of the morning to acquire the fruits and later sell them from community to community. Her wish is to see her children grow up to have careers and for them to be upstanding citizens. She is profoundly thankful for the opportunity that is given her. 

All of the members are responsible, hardworking women who are thankful to the organization for the support provided to them.

loans.use: to purchase seasonal fruit.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah N. is 40 years old and lives in the town of Makindye in the Kampala central region of Uganda. She is married and has four children, three of whom are currently in school. Sarah has a poultry business, which she has run for ten years.
To help expand her business, Sarah has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more chickens for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Sarah hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, she hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more chickens for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more bags for resale.

loans.name: Kiduusu Women's Group

texts.en: 29 year old Sarah N. has been operating a pub for close to 5 years now in Kiduusu-Lugazi. She is affiliated with Kiduusu Women's group and she says she set forth in this business with savings from her food sales business. Sarah is happily married with 5 kids and says that running this business has been worthwhile in many ways, especially in that it has enabled her to fully support and provide for her family. She says her monthly business profits are about 38,000 shillings. With this Kiva loan, Sarah says she is going to purchase more crates of both hard and soft beverages to resell at her pub.

loans.use: to purchase more crates of both hard and soft beverages to resell at her pub.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim is 35 years old and lives in the town of Ggaba in the Kampala central region of Uganda. He is married and has three children. All of his children are currently in school. Ibrahim has a poultry business, which he has run for five years.         
To help expand his business, Ibrahim has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more chickens for resale. With the help of his loan from BRAC, Ibrahim hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children.  In the future, he hopes to expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase more chickens for resale.

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet N. is 33 years old and lives in the town of Ggaba in the Kampala central region of Uganda. She is married and has five children, four of whom are currently in school. Harriet has a small retail shop business, which she has run for five years.
To help expand her business, Harriet has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase essential commodities, such as sugar, for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Harriet hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, she hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase essential commodities, such as sugar, for resale.

loans.name: Sotogbé

texts.fr: Revendeuse de divers produits (marmites, bassines, plats,…….) depuis 1996  et mariée à un maçon, Mme Sotogbé a 42 ans et mère de 05 enfants. Elle s’approvisionne de temps en temps au grand marché de Lomé et revend à domicile à toutes les couches sociales. Avec ce second crédit elle veut sortir son activité de la maison  pour se faire connaître de la population et  accroître son commerce.
texts.en: Selling various items (pots, bowls, platters, etc.) since 1996 and married to a mason, Mrs. Sotogbé is 42 and the mother of five children. She buys her wares from time to time at the Grand Market of Lomé and sells the items out of her house, to people from all walks of life. With this second loan, she wants to bring her business out of her house so as to become known in the neighborhood and expand her little enterprise.

loans.use: to buy bowls and other household items.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane N. is 55 years old and lives in the town of Ggaba in the Kampala central region of Uganda. She is single and has six children, none of whom are currently in school. Jane has a small retail shop business, which she has run for ten years.
To help expand her business, Jane has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase essential commodities, such as soap, for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Jane hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, she hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase essential commodities, such as soap, for resale.

loans.name: Ziliat

texts.en:
Ziliat N. is 50 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli in the Kampala central region of Uganda. She is single and has four children, none of whom are currently in school. Ziliat has a small retail shop business, which she has run for three years.
To help expand her business, Ziliat has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase essential commodities, such as cooking oil, for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Ziliat hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, she hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase essential commodities, such as cooking oil, for resale.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es: La señora francisca se dedica hace 17 años a la venta D. chompas para hombres, mujeres y niños en un puesto fijo ubicado En una zona muy comercial, D. la ciudad D. la paz. Comenzando con un capital mínimo, poco a poco logró incrementar su mercadería hasta tener un puesto surtido con todo tipo D. chompas en distintos colores y distintos precios, vive en alquiler en la zona D. san Antonio junto  a su esposo y a sus hijos, con mucho esfuerzo lograron sacar adelante a su familia. Actualmente su esposo trabaja D. garzón y todos sus hijos excepto uno son independientes, doña francisca saco el crédito para incrementar su capital ya que la época D. invierno se adelantó y en está época es donD. aumentan sus ventas y con el dinero del crédito comprara chompas y sacones por mayor,  es una cliente que a lo largo D. estos años demostró responsabilidad, cumplimiento y puntualidad, esta agradecida con la institución por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en: For the past 17 years Francisca has been selling sweaters for men, women, and children from a fixed stand located in a highly commercial region in the city of La Paz. She started out with a minimal capital fund but gradually she increased her merchandise until she achieved to have a variety of sweaters of different styles, colors, and prices. She lives in a rental unit in the region of San Antonio together with her husband and children. They have managed to support their family with a great deal of effort. Her husband works as a waiter and their children are independent, except for one. Francisca accessed a loan to increase her capital because the winter season came early and this is when her sales increase. With the funds from the loan she will purchase sweater and jackets in wholesale. She is a client who has demonstrated responsibility, commitment, and punctuality throughout the years. She is thankful to the organization for their support.

loans.use: to purchase sweaters for the winter season.

loans.name: Mayi

texts.en:
Mayi S. is 44 years old and lives in the town of Kitintale in the Kampala central region of Uganda. She is single and has two children, both of whom are currently in school. Mayi has a small retail shop business, which she has run for six years.
To help expand her business, Mayi has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase essential commodities, such as bread, for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Mayi hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, she hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase essential commodities, such as bread, for resale.

loans.name: Gladys Ricarda

texts.es: Gladys Ricarda tiene su actividad que es la venta de granos básicos. Ella ha demostrado ser una persona muy humilde y sincera. A pesar de los problemas que ha enfrentado como es la difícil situación económica por la que el país atraviesa. Tiene dos hijos, a su cargo Ella además de estar al tanto de sus hijos también se dedica al comercio,  trabaja todos los días desde las 6 de la mañana hasta las 7 de la noche. Lleva 12 años que se dedica a esta actividad y le ha ido muy bien. Este crédito es para comprar más productos como arroz, aceite, frijoles, concentrado, maíz entre otros productos.
texts.en: Gladys Ricarda has a business selling basic grains. She has demonstrated herself to be a very humble and sincere person. She has faced the problems from the difficult financial situation that the country is going through. She has 2 children in her care. In addition to caring for her children she is also a merchant.
