payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rosenda

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, Rosenda works hard to support her family. She has a dried fish vending business in the Philippines, and she also earns additional income from fishing.  Rosenda is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to buy bamboo for her dried fish business.

Rosenda has been sustaining her business activities through her past 12 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream: to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy bamboo for her sun-dried fish business.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia Consul is married and 41 years old. She has a retail shop where she sells different products. Alicia has had this business for nine years.

Alicia is requesting a loan of 24,000 PHP to buy products to sell like drinks, soap, and toothpaste. Each month Alicia earns about 8,000 PHP doing this type of work.

In the future, Alicia hopes that her business will further improve to earn more income.

loans.use: to buy products to sell like drinks, soap, and toothpaste.

loans.name: Dorolea

texts.en:
Dorolea L. is from the village of Bolison, Kinoguitan, Misamis Oriental. She is 49 years old. Dorolea is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Dorolea owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling seafood products  including fish like "katambak", "lapu-lapu" & "magmocat" in the local community. Dorolea has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Dorolea joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dorolea is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish like sardines & milk fish. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Dorolea from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish like sardines & milk fish.

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en:
Angelita is 45 years old and is a married woman with three children. Her oldest child is 22 years old.

Angelita is a farmer working in Banga, South Cotabato. She has been growing rice for 22 years. Angelita works hard to help sustain her family. She also wants to save for her children's future.

Angelita needs seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She has requested a loan and plans to use it to fund her farm. Angelita hopes for her harvest to improve.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Donis Francisco

texts.es:
Donis, nacido en la comunidad Santa Rosa – La Rica comarca de Yali, tiene  36 años de edad, esta casado, tiene 4 hijos, de oficio agricultor el se dedica a la siembra de café . Inicio trabajando en la siembra de frijol y maíz  para ese entonces el tenia 15 años de edad, el ayudaba a su papa en las labores agrícolas, después su papa le ayudo a sembrar 2 manzanas de café así ha venido manteniendo a su familia, sus hijos estudian. Cuando las cosechas  están bajas el se dedica a vender granos básicos, el no pudo estudiar pues el acceso a las escuelas eran distancias muy lejanas.  
El solicito el crédito para mantenimiento 2 manzanas de siembra de café .De esta inversión espera poder sacar una buena producción de calidad y rendimiento, venderlo a un buen precio el quintal de cafe. El tiene entre sus planes aumentar las aéreas de la siembra para cafe. Tiene como próxima meta comercializar en mayor cantidad granos básicos, construir una bodega para almacenar café.
texts.en:
Donis, 36, was born in the community of Santa Rosa-La Rica, Yali.   He’s married and has four children.  He’s a coffee planter.  He started out farming beans and corn when he was 15 years old; he helped his father do the farming chores.  Later, his father helped him plant two manzanas (Central American measure of area) of coffee and this is how he’s been supporting his family; his children all go to school.  When harvests are low he goes into basic grain sales.  He was unable to go to school because schools were too far away.

He asked for the loan to care for his coffee crops.  From this investment he hopes to attain a good production both with respect to quality and quantity and to sell it for a good price.  

Among his plans is expanding the area he plants.  His next goal is to sell larger amounts of basic grains and to build a warehouse to store coffee.

loans.use: to care for his coffee crops.

loans.name: Tam

texts.en: Tam T. N. is 43 years old with 2 children who are married. She lives in the Yen Phong district. Many years ago, she opened a shop that provides internet service. Her shop was already much developed when she received a loan in 2007 and invested it. Since that time, she has passed through five loan cycles successfully. For the previous loan cycle, she received 8,288,000 Vietnamese dong to invest in enlarging her space for more customer seating. For  the new loan cycle, she is requesting a loan of 9,184,000 Vietnamese dong to upgrade her internet service by buying new computers to attract customers.

loans.use: to buy new computers to attract customers

loans.name: Susime

texts.en: Susime is a hard working entrepreneur who has a salt selling business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 25 years. Susime earns more income from pig fattening. Susime has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from Kiva's partner, NWTF. She dreams of saving money to expand her business in the future. She is now borrowing PHP 29,500 through NWTF to buy more salt for resale.

loans.use: To buy more salt to sell

loans.name: Lea

texts.en:
Lea Ortiz is a 51-year-old married woman living in the Philippines. Lea has five children and her spouse works as a farmer.

Lea has been in the business of selling medicines and other food supplements for three years. She earns approximately PHP 3,000 per month. She is requesting a loan of PHP 7,000. She plans to use this loan to purchase additional medicines like paracetamol (acetaminophen) and antibiotics to sell in the community.

In the future, Lea hopes that her business will improve and expand to support the needs of her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional medicines like paracetamol(acetaminophen) and antibiotics to sell

loans.name: Oeurn

texts.en:
Oeurn S. and her husband work by planting mushrooms around their house. From this business, this family normally earns an average of $4 per day to help cover their family’s daily living expenses. Presently, when Oeurn S. needs to use the water, she always goes to take it from her neighbor’s well because she doesn’t have a well of her own.  Oeurn S. is seeking a Kiva loan to dig a well for the whole family to use and to expand  her mushroom-planting business. 
Oeurn S., her young baby and her old mother appear in the photo.

loans.use: to dig a well and also to expand  her mushroom-planting business.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet is 41 years old and married with three children, of whom two are in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Janet has a dried fish vending business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 10 years. In the future, Janet would like to save money to expand her business. Janet requested a PHP 24,000 loan through Kiva's partner, NWTF, to buy bamboo on which to dry fish for sale.

loans.use: To buy bamboo for drying fish to sell

loans.name: Lorenza

texts.en: Lorenza is 67 years old and widowed with three children. Lorenza has a fishing business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 20 years. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. In the future, Lorenza would like to save money to expand her business. She requested a loan of PHP 22,000 through Kiva's partner, NWTF, to pay for maintenance for her fish cage.

loans.use: to pay for the maintenance of her fish cage

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Divina

texts.en: Divina is 40 years of age and married to a farmer with three children. They live harmoniously in the village of Gappal, Cauayan City, Isabela. She has a retail store that she has operated for almost 20 years. She sells grocery products such as sugar, coffee, milk, canned goods, and beverages. She earns PHP 6,000 monthly. She is requesting a loan from KIVA and ASKI for PHP 13,000 to purchase additional grocery items to sell in her retail store. In the future, she hopes to expand her business and gain more income to uplift their way of living.

loans.use: to purchase grocery items to sell in her retail store

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en: As a married parent of eight children, Marivic works hard to support her family. She has a business selling perfumes in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from farming rice. Marivic has been sustaining her business activities through her past 11 loans from Kiva's partner, NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough to provide a secure future for her family. Marivic is requesting a loan of PHP 15,000 through NWTF to buy more stocks of perfume to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more perfumes to sell

loans.name: Mildred

texts.en:
Mildred is a hardworking entrepreneur who buys and sells garlic and onions in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to buy garlic and onions to sell in her food stall.

Mildred has been in this business for nine years. She also earns income from fattening pigs.

Mildred has been developing her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough money  to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: To buy garlic and onions to sell in her stall

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en: Angelita is married and she is 60 years old. She has a tailoring shop in their village. She makes curtains and clothes. Angelita is asking for a loan for PHP 13,000 to purchase materials needed for her business like needles, thread and cloth. Her husband is a farmer. She has had her business for almost 20 years and earns PHP 6,000 monthly. She will use her profits for additional business to gain more income. She hopes that ASKI and KIVA will continue to support her business.

loans.use: to purchase needles, thread and cloth

loans.name: Monina

texts.en:
Monina is 46 years old and married with six children, five of whom are in school.

Monina has been a vegetable farmer in the Philippines for eight years. She requested a loan of PHP19,000 through NWTF to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies. This will be her eleventh loan from NWTF.

Monina would like to continue to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: To buy fertlizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna is 56 years old and married with eight children, one of whom is in school.

Myrna has been a sugarcane farmer in the Philippines for ten years. She requested a PHP15,000 loan through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies. This will be her nineteenth loan from NWTF.

In the future, Myrna would like to save enough to buy more farm land.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ella Romero's Group

texts.en: Ella is 26 years old and married. She has a general store where she sells products like toothpaste, soap, soft drinks and other commodities. Ella has been managing this business for over four years and she earns approximately PHP 5,000 monthly. Ella is requesting a loan of 12,000 PHP to purchase products like soft drinks, vinegar and soap to sell in their community. In the future, Ella hopes that her business will grow further for the benefit of her family.

loans.use: to purchase products to sell like soft drinks, vinegar and soap.

loans.name: Luciana

texts.en:
Luciana sells frozen products in her community. She has been in this business for two years. Luciana is thankful to have this business for she is able to provide her family with their daily needs.

Luciana is requesting PHP 13,000 to buy frozen products like bologna, cured pork and sausages for sale. She sells these products once a week and is earning PHP 4,000 net income each month. 

At the age of 59, she is already a widow with five children. She solely manages her family towards prosperity. Being a single parent is very difficult but Luciana brings her best to meet their needs.  She hopes to create a sustainable livelihood for her family in the future.

loans.use: to buy frozen products like bologna, cured pork and sausages to sell

loans.name: Vicenta

texts.en:
Vicenta B. is from the village of South Cogon, Misamis Oriental. She is 82 years old. Vicenta is widowed and has four adult-aged children. She operates a specialized retail store buying and selling bananas and coconuts in the local community. Vicenta has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 1996, Vicenta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16000 PHP. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and provide working capital. Vicenta is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional bananas and coconuts. This loan will be her 15th loan from HSPFI.  

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional bananas and coconuts

loans.name: Visitacion

texts.en:
Visitacion is 42 years old and married with three children, two of whom are in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur with a business buying and selling garlic and onions in the Philippines. Visitacion requested a PHP10,000 loan through NWTF to buy more inventory.

Visitacion has been in this business for six years. In the future, she would like to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: To buy garlic and oinons to sell in her food stall

loans.name: Benjie

texts.en:
Benjie is a farmer working in Banga, South Cotabato. He is 34 years old, and married with two children. Benjie primarily grows rice to sell. He tills his own land and prepares it well. He also grows cassava on some of his land. Benjie sells his harvest at the market.

Benjie has requested a loan and plans to use it to purchase fertilizer and other farm supplies. He hopes for his business to grow. He said he wants to improve his family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Det

texts.en:
Det S. has been a farmer for a long-time. She uses her own farmland to plant a rice crop as an annual activity. She can generate an income of around $2.50 each day from her crop-growing business. In order to help support Det S., her husband works as a driver making a profit of approximately  US$3 a day.  Det S. has three children, two of whom also work as drivers for a private company while the other is a  student and a dependent. 

Det S. has been paying money for taxis because she doesn't own a vehicle. To solve this problem, she is applying for a loan to purchase a used motorcycle.

loans.use: to purchase a used motorcycle.

loans.name: Tang

texts.en:
Tang T. N. is 49 years old living in Yen phong district with two children. 

Tang was a teacher for 19 years, but found that the salary was low for trying to send her two children to college. In 2009, she decided to participate in our credit program with the hope of taking a loan to open a repair shop for motorbikes that her husband could manage.  

Her business is now doing well and provides a stable income to help support her family. She used her last loan of 8,288,000 Vietnamese dong to buy motor parts. For the new loan, she is requesting 9,184,000 Vietnamese dong to buy additional machinery.

loans.use: to buy machinery for her motorbike repair shop.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is asking for a loan of PHP 20,000 that will serve as additional capital to buy hog feeds. She also wanted to buy vegetables to sell to generate extra income. Josephine hopes to give her family a progressive living. That is why she is working hard and diligently looking for extra sources of income.

Josephine is 23 years old, a young mother to her child. Her husband works as a truck driver. She has been raising fattening pigs for more than a year now. Her income from business, which is PHP 8,000 whenever she sells one of her raised pigs, is being used for their daily basic needs. In the future, Josephine wishes to become successful in her chosen business.

loans.use: to buy hog feed

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Many people aim for simplicity, because as Richard Bach once said, “The simplest things are often the truest.” This principle is evident in the life of Jennifer S., 33. Jennifer is married to Lino, a security guard. Together they are raising two children, one of whom is in elementary school, while the other is still too young to attend school. They have been living in Silang, Cavite the last five years.

Jennifer has a sari-sari (variety) store which she operates on her own every day. It is her daily task to check on which items and which specific brands her customers prefer. After her three years of experience in this kind of micro enterprise, she knows the tastes of her customers and earns PHP9,000 monthly.

To help her use the information she has, she is requesting a PHP10,000 loan. She will use it increase her inventory of the most popular items, such as  rice, canned goods, soft drinks, and other daily essentials. 

It is inevitable for sari-sari store owners to have customers who do not pay their debts. But Jennifer strives to get past this challenge to make her life simpler and better. As much as she wants her business to grow, she desires to have another baby and to lead a simple life. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meetings where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: to buy additional merchandise for her store

loans.name: Puspa Kencana Group

texts.en: Ni Putu, 27, is the leader of the group called Puspa Kencana, consisting of 10 members. They are receiving a loan of Rp. 15,000,000 with each member receiving Rp. 1,500,000. Currently, Ni Putu already has a local type of pigs and she will use the loan to buy a superior species of pigs. The price for superior pigs is more expensive than the local species because of the quality of the meat. She hopes by maintaining the superior pigs, she will get more profit so she can help with the needs of her family.

loans.use: To buy a superior variety of pigs

loans.name: Bella Domingo's Group

texts.en: Bella is the leader of 11 members taking a group loan. Bella is married and 35 years old. She has a retailing business where she sells soap, shampoo, bread, soft drinks and other products required for daily use by her co-villagers. She has operated this business for almost five years. Bella is requesting a loan of PHP 15,000 to purchase soft drinks, bread, canned goods and sugar to sell in her village. She usually earns about PHP 7,000 each month in this business. She hopes that her business will improve through the loan.

loans.use: to purchase sugar, canned goods, soft drinks and bread to sell

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en:
Luisa A. is now 44 years old and married with two school-aged children. Luisa is a farmer who works in the Philippines and earns approximately PHP 10,000 per month. 

Luisa is asking for a loan of PHP 18,000 to pay to prepare their corn plantation. Luisa has been growing corn for 10 years.  In the future, Luisa hopes to strengthen their corn production business as one source of their income. She believes that with her strong faith and determination, she can improve their status of living and give their children a bright future.

loans.use: to pay to prepare their corn plantation

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
If one wants to improve, she has to keep her eyes forward and act prudently. Rosalinda V., 46, learned this at a young age and aims to keep an eye on the future of her business and family. She has only finished high school, but looking forward, she has the rest of her life to spend with her husband, Florante, an aircraft maintenance personnel. Also, three bright futures are in their hands as they take care of three children. Together, they live in Silang, Cavite, Philippines.

Rosalinda owns a sari-sari (variety) store. She sells daily essentials such as shampoo, canned goods, and beverages. Aside from this store, she also has a small computer shop and a billiard shop, all located in their community. She has been in this micro business for three years now, and she earns around PHP11,000 monthly.

To help her continue running her business, she applied for a PHP30,000 loan. She will use this money to buy another computer to meet the demands of her clients. Also, she will purchase grocery items to add to her store shelves. Rosalinda is grateful for the help being extended to her business, as it is what keeps her family up and going every day.

Being a sari-sari store owner, it is difficult for her to follow up with customers who have long lists of debts. But Rosalinda continues to devise strategies to meet this difficulty. Rosalinda also aims to save enough for old age. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meetings where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.


*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: to buy additional items for her variety store

loans.name: Hermane

texts.en:
Hermane P. is from the village of Bolisong, Kinoguitan, Misamis Oriental. She is 54 years old and married withfour adult-aged children. Hermane  runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where she sells canned goods, snack foods, beverages, shampoo, soap and biscuits in the local community. Hermane has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Hermane joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services. Hermane has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to purchase additional inventory and provide working capital. Hermane is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase snack foods and canned goods to sell. This will be her fifth loan from HSPFI. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional snack foods and canned goods

loans.name: Ligaya

texts.en:
Ligaya A. is now 50 years of age and married with four adult-aged children. Ligaya is a farmer working in the Philippines and earns approximately PHP 5,000 per month. 

Ligaya is asking for a loan of PHP 12,000 to pay for services to prepare their corn plantation. Ligaya has been growing corn for 12 years.

In the future, Ligaya hopes that they can produce more corn and earn a higher income. She believes that someday they can start another kind of business through the financial assistance of the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to pay for preparation of their corn plantation

loans.name: Apolonia

texts.en:
Growth is very important in life, as it indicates progress and not subtle death. Apolonia D., 42, believes in this and incorporates it in her beliefs, business, and lifestyle. Apolonia finished a degree in AB Library Science in college, and is married to Nelson, a driver. She is also an active community partner of CCT*. Two children were born into their family, one is studying in elementary school and one who is not yet of school age. Their family resides in Munting Ilog, Silang, Cavite.

At present, Apolonia is focusing on growing her businesses— a public transportation business and an agricultural garden grown for profit. Each day her husband goes out to provide transportation services to people in their community. The fruits, vegetables, and ornamental plants being grown in her agricultural garden are being sold in the market for profit. Apolonia has been doing this for ten years now. Every month, her perseverance yields her an average of Php11,900.

To help her continue the operations of her business, Apolonia is requesting a loan of 19,000 PHP.  She believes that this is one step to take in order for her to grow her business. She sees applying for this loan as a great help to her. With the loan money on hand, she intends to buy essential materials for her jeepney transport business. She will purchase wheels and other spare parts for the improvement and maintenance of the vehicle. Apolonia sees this loan as a great opportunity for growth, and she prays that the Lord will continually bless those people whom He uses to bless her and her family.

It becomes a real challenge to Apolonia whenever the jeepney goes under repair, since it is one of their main source of business income. But she refuses to back down and finds ways to solve the dilemma. Apolonia believes that soon, her business will grow, even the agricultural garden she grows for additional profit. Above everything else, she prays that her children will grow to become successful in completing their education. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.


*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: to buy parts to maintain her jeepney vehicle

loans.name: Alexander

texts.en:
Alexander G. is from the village of Barangay 4, Talakag, Bukidnon. He is 49 years old. Alexander is single. 

To make a living, Alexander owns & operates a business providing hairdressing & beauty services to local community members. He has been engaged in his business for over 13 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities. Alexander belongs to the third sex.

In 2009, Alexander joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to expand the services provided. 

Alexander is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase tools needed to maintain service. This loan will be his 4th loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tools for his hairdressing business

loans.name: Katlyn

texts.en:
Sustainability matters a lot in business and Katlyn R., 27, understands its importance. Being an entrepreneur at a relatively young age, Katlyn strives to do her best to improve her business and to provide for her two children who depend on her. One of her children is studying in elementary school, and the younger one is not yet of school age. Katlyn lives with them in Munting Ilog, Silang, Cavite.

Katlyn runs her own sari-sari (variety) store seling to people in her community.  She is able to balance both being an entrepreneur and a single mom. She also manages to attend weekly fellowships and trainings in CCT* as a community partner. Through her sari-sari store, Katlyn is able to serve her community by meeting their needs with quality and affordable products. Every month she earns around Php 7,000.

Because she is in need of help to empower her in sustaining her business, Katlyn decides to seek a loan Php10,000. She plans to use this loan to purchase quality brands for her store. She intends to buy sacks of rice, boxes of canned goods, instant noodles, and soft drinks which are sought after by customers in the hot weather of the country. Katlyn acknowledges that this loan will greatly help her in sustaining not just her business but also her family.

Like many micro entrepreneurs, Katlyn struggles with customers who do not pay their debt. But because her goal is to grow and become sustainable, she works on ways to handle this difficulty. Most of all, it is her ultimate goal to be able to provide schooling for her children up to college. 

As a CCT community partner, Katlyn faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional items for her variety store

loans.name: Japarbek's Group

texts.en:
Japarbek T. is a member of this group. He is a resident of Bokonbaevo, a small village located on the south coast of Lake Isykul. He is 44 and  is married to a nurse. Together with his wife, he brings up a thirteen-year-old child who currently attends school. In order to provide for his family, Japarbek cultivates agricultural products and selling some part of the harvest each month. This activity made it possible for him to improve his family’s living conditions. With the money received from this loan, Japarbek wants to purchase a variety of seeds and fuel for his farm.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fuel

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma S. is from the village of Sto. Niño. She is 48 years old. Wilma is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Wilma owns & operates a specialized retail store, selling different kinds of daily needs items such as soap, coffee, cooking oil, soy sauce, green onions, and other vegetables. Wilma has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2680 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2011, Wilma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions for her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches branches and covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rapiya's Group

texts.en:
Rapiya O. is the treasurer of this group. She is 52 and is married. Together with her husband who is now a pensioner, she raised three daughters and two sons. Their youngest son studies at school, and their other children are married and live separately with their families. 

In 1992, Rapiya's family started to breed cattle. They resell farm animals at a higher price after fattening them.  From this business, the family earns 8000 soms per month. Rapiya has applied for this loan because she needs money to purchase three livestock animals for breeding. She hopes to obtain this loan, which will help her to realize the plans. In the future, Rapiya wants to provide her younger son a good education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Tuon's Group

texts.en:
To earn a living, Tuon P. sells groceries in the province. She is a widowed mother who is blessed with two children. Mrs. Tuon P., age 42, has been selected as the leader of the five people from her group. Tuon P. will be using her loan in order to purchase additional grocery items to sell. 

There are four other people who belong to this group:
Mrs. S., a clothes vender, who is asking for a loan to buy additional clothes to sell.
Mrs. S., a taxi driver, who is requesting a loan to repair her old house.
Mr. S., a fish seller, who is seeking his loan to buy more fish to sell.
Mrs. C. will be using her loan to buy a new motorcycle.

loans.use: to buy additional grocery items to sell.

loans.name: Emilyn

texts.en:
Emilyn L. is from the village of Tabo-o, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 23 years old and is married. To make a living, Emilyn owns & operates a fish business, buying and selling fish in the local community.  She is just starting this business.

In 2011, Emilyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emilyn is requesting a loan of 40000 PHP to purchase additional fish to sell. This will be her first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches and three  covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Knarik

texts.en:
Knarik J. lives in Tsovagyugh village, Gegharkunik Marz, with her parents and brother, who is a student at Yerevan.
  
Knarik works at the village school as a German teacher.  At the same time, she is also engaged in farming to earn additional income. On her farm she has cows, calves and chickens, which she raises with help from family members.  They also grow oats.  Thanks to this farming income, Knarik’s family can meet their needs and pay for Knarik’s brother's education. 

Knarik is seeking a loan for 1,000,000 AMD to increase her farming livestock and to buy oat seedlings.

loans.use: To buy more livestock and oat seedlings

loans.name: Thlok

texts.en: Thlok O. is 33 years old and a resident of Kompong Tom province, where she earns a living raising piglets in a cage behind her house. She is married with a child who is enrolled in a local school. Her husband, Mr. Bil Khim, sells firewood in and around the village. Besides raising pigs, she has also been planting the rice crop that is her annual business. Thlok O. has applied for a loan from Kiva’s partner HKL in order to purchase fertilizers, seeds, and hire a plowing machine to plow her farmland.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds, and to hire a plowing machine to plow her farmland

loans.name: Burulai's Group

texts.en:
Burulai B. is the treasurer of this group. She is 39 and is married to a farmer. Together with her husband, Burulai are bringing up two sons –  both of whom are of pre-school age (under seven). 

In 1993, Burulai's family received a piece of land from the Kyrgyz government.  Since that time, her family has been cultivating cotton and corn. Each month, they sell a part of the harvest.  From this work, the family earns 7000 soms per month. 

With money gained from this farming activity, Burulai was able to purchase home furniture and improve their living conditions.  She hopes to obtain this loan because she needs additional money to purchase seeds and fertilizers for farming. In the future, Burulai dreams of purchasing an apartment in Bishkek and of providing her sons with the best education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers for her farm

loans.name: Amartuvshin

texts.en:
Mr. Amartuvshin is 24 years old.  He lives with his wife and 1-year-old daughter in Darkhan, the second largest city in Mongolia. His family owns a small plot of land with a house on it. 

Amartuvshin’s wife is a chef and runs a small diner at the moment.  She is planning to expand it to a cafeteria in the future. Amartuvshin runs a taxi business using his family car. 

The house which Amartuvshin bought a few years ago is in heavy need of renovation. The house does not keep its warmth during the winter and the roof leaks during the rainy season.  They have to burn more coal to make the house warm during the winter, which means that they release more smoke  than the average household, polluting the air.  The walls and roof need to be properly insulated and fixed. 

Amartuvshin is planning to put foam insulation in the walls and roof to make the house warmer and to replace the windows and roof tiles. The loan he is requesting will be used to buy foam insulation materials for the walls and to replace the windows and roof tiles with new ones.

loans.use: To buy materials to fix his home

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy recyclable materials.

loans.name: Sang

texts.en: The photo above shows Mrs. Sang S. who sells a variety of items from her own store which she operates from her house. She is 45 and married, and has been blessed with five single children: one of them is employed as a salaried security guard. Her husband is a motor taxi (Tuk Tuk) driver in and around the province of Siem Reap. Mrs. Sang S. is a busy woman who works hard every day at her business in order to earn the money to help support her family. She will use part of this Kiva loan as capital to purchase more items to sell, and the rest of the loan to mend her husband’s motorcycle.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell, and the rest of the loan to mend her husband’s motorcycle

loans.name: Von

texts.en: Von C. is a 30-year-old married woman who earns a daily income by producing clay crocodile to sell to her regular clients in bulk from her house. On average, Von C. makes a profit of about $2 per day. She also has other financial earner in her husband who is a boat deliverer in Siem Reap province. Recently her husband has been finding it difficult to catch as many fishes as before, since his boat is broken. So Von C. is applying for a loan to repair the old boat for her husband. Von C. is blessed with four children, all of whom are not yet working and living under her income.

loans.use: to repair the old boat for her husband.

loans.name: Banco Mujer Hacia Adelante Group

texts.es:
Doña Fátima es la presidenta de Banco Mujer Hacia Adelante,  una señora muy trabajadora, de 42 años de edad, madre de 5 hijos, y de nacionalidad Nicaragüense, que no tuvo la oportunidad de seguir estudiando, y solo asistió a primaria.  

Se enteró de los servicios de Fundación Mujer por medio de una vecina de su comunidad, y este es su primer crédito, se dedica a vA. actividades como; comercio, pequeña industria y servicios de venta de comida, el  crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de ropa americana, telas para la elaboración de ropa e insumos para la elaboración de comidas rápidas. 

La clienta tiene su negocio hace más de 5 años, y el principal obstáculo que ha tenido que enfrentar es la falta de dinero para invertir en sus actividades, para hacer crecer sus negocios, y mejorar la calidad de vida de ella y su familia. Por eso tiene sus metas y objetivos bien definidos, entre ellos están, adquirir más conocimientos en el tema de manipulación de alimentos , tener su propia soda para vender todo tipo de comida, al igual que un carro para ir a comunidades alejadas a vender ropa. Son algunos de los sueños que se ha propuesto lograr con mucho trabajo y dedicación. 

El crédito va hacer de gran ayuda para Fátima y sus 7 compañeras del banco, que se dedican al comercio y avicultura.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fátima, 42, is the President of the “Mujer Hacia Adelante” (Woman Forward) communal bank.  She is a very hard working mother of five children.  She is Nicaraguan and did not have the opportunity to continue her schooling beyond elementary school.

She found out about Fundación Mujer’s services through an invitation from a neighbor.  This is her first loan.  She does a variety of things: commerce, small industry and food services.  She will invest the loan in purchasing American clothes, fabric for clothes manufacturing and ingredients to make fast food.

The client has had her business for over 5 years.  The main obstacle she’s faced is the lack of money to invest in her activities to make her businesses grow and improve her family’s and her own quality of life.  Because of this she has well defined goals.  Among them are: to acquire more skills in food handling, to have her own snack bar to sell all types of food as well as a car to go to distant communities to sell clothes.  These are some of the dreams she’s set up for herself that she plans to accomplish through much effort and dedication.

The loan will help Fátima and her seven fellow bank members, who are in commerce and raising barnyard fowl, quite a bit.

loans.use: to buy clothes, fabric and food ingredients.

loans.name: Daviriana

texts.en:
Daviriana is a 41-year-old entrepreneur. She owns a small business selling rice in Oeba and Inpres Markets. Daviriana is married to Ishak who is a 45 -year-old farmer. They have been blessed with seven children, namely: Daud, 23 years old and graduated from Senior High School, Paulina, 21 years old and studying in nursing academic, Ronald, 18 years old and in the third grade of Senior High School, Alex, 11 years old and in the 5th grade of elementary school, Ferdy, 6 years old, Ratna, 5 years old and Angle, 4 years old. Daviriana and her family reside in Merdeka Village. 

Daviriana initiated her business by using her own capital. Due to the capital limitation, Daviriana can only sell rice in a small quantity. Daviriana has been thinking of increasing her income from this business. There are many rice fields owned by the local community in her village and they usually sell at harvest so there is an opportunity for Daviriana to buy rice from them to sell in the market. 

Daviriana is requesting a loan amounting to IDR 10,000,000 from TLM. She intends to use the loan to purchase rice in large quantities. She believes that the business will have a good impact on her family in the future. Daviriana is hoping that TLM will approve her loan application.

loans.use: To purchase rice in large quantities

loans.name: Lodya

texts.en:
Lodya is a 37-year-old lady married to Titus, 40 years old. From the marriage, they have been blessed with two children: Dicky, 15 years old, who is in the third grade of junior high school and Devi, 15 years old, who is in the second grade of junior high school. They live in Nunhila Village  

Lodya has been running a kiosk business for two years. From this business, Lodya can support her husband Titus in meeting their daily needs and educational needs of her children. Since the children are growing up, their needs are increasing. Lodya dreams of improving her business by adding more stock to her kiosk.    

Lodya is requesting a loan of IDR 5,000,000 as additional capita. She plans to use the loan to purchase more stocks, i.e: rice, cooking oil, instant noodles, kerosene, sugar, coffee, milk, etc. She is really hoping that TLM is willing to assist her in improving her kiosk business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of rice, cooking oil, instant noodles, kerosene, sugar, coffee, milk, etc.

loans.name: Benjie

texts.en:
Benjie is a 27-year-old married man who lives in the town of Banga, South Cotabato. He is a farmer and has been growing rice for 15 years. Benjie also opened a sari-sari store to help augment his family's income. His wife is the one managing the store.

Benjie applied for a loan and plans to use it to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs. Benjie hopes to have a stable business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Celestino

texts.en:
Celestino is a farmer from the town of Banga, South Cotabato. He has been growing rice for 22 years. Celestino sells his harvest to rice traders. He earns 5,000 PHP from his farming business. Celestino works hard to provide the needs of his family. He started raising pigs to help augment their income. He also applied for a loan so he could fund his farm. He plans to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

Celestino is 39 years old and married with two young children. He hopes to save enough money to sustain his children's education.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 32 years old, married and has two children.

Ahmad is a butcher. In 2006, he opened his shop where he sells meat. He has more than five years experience in this field, and has a good reputation and he is well known.

He is requesting $3,000 to repair his shop’s walls and floors. He is aiming to expand his business so he is able to improve his family's quality life.

loans.use: To repair his shop’s walls and floors.

loans.name: Chanthou

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthou H. (pictured here) is 38 years old, and her husband, Mr. Pechh Keang, is 39 years old. The couple has been married since 1994 and have six children: four sons and two daughters. Two are garment factory workers, three attend school, and another one is still too young for school. The family lives in a village about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia.

Chanthou is a mango farmer, and her husband is a mason. She is asking for her first loan of $1,200 to renovate and concrete the house where she lives.

loans.use: To renovate and concrete the house where she lives

loans.name: Ma. Clarita

texts.en:
As a married parent of six children, Ma. Clarita works hard to support her family. She has a fishing business in the Philippines and earns additional income as a food vendor. Ma. Clarita has requested a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) through NWTF to buy fishing gear and equipment for her fishing business.

Ma. Clarita has supported her business activities through 12 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: To buy fishing gear and equipment

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 33 years old, married and has three children.

In 2003 Hussein opened his own shop selling shoes for women and men. He has five years' experience in this field and has a good reputation and he is well known in his area.

He is requesting $2100 loan to make an aluminum door and shelves for his shop. He is aiming to expand his business so he will be able to improve his family's quality of life.

loans.use: to make an aluminum door and shelves for his shop.

loans.name: Vanna

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanna and her husband, Mr. Sam, both pictured above, have been married since 2005. Mr. Sam is a fisherman and also raises ducks at home. The couple has two young sons who are in school. The family lives in a suburb of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia.

Vanna is a tailor and assists her husband in his duck-raising business. She asked for a Kiva loan to purchase additional ducks for her husband to raise. She hopes to buy more and keep increasing their flock, hence her request for another loan of US$ 600. Vanna was able to successfully repay a previous loan on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase additional ducks for her husband to raise

loans.name: Joy Ann

texts.en:
As a community partner in CCT,* Joy Ann F. proves to the world that not having any tertiary (post-secondary) education cannot stop her from living life to its fullest. At 38, Joy Ann heads a family with her husband George, a policeman. She and George have three children; two are attending school, while the third is too young to study. They used to live in Davao City, but currently they live in Ascoville, Caloocan City, Metro Manila.

Joy Ann finds fellowship in CCT as a sari-sari (variety) store owner, like many of her fellow community partners. Her store is located next to the family home, and she sells daily essentials such as beverages, detergents, and candies. Part of her inventory is electronic loads from different service providers for mobile phones (i.e., prepaid cell phone credits, mainly used for text messaging). She has been in business for three years now, and every month she earns around 11,000 Philippine pesos (PHP).

To help her take her business to the next level, she has applied for a loan of 10,000 PHP. She will invest the money in buying sacks of rice, which are always in demand in the Philippines, and supplies of electronic load. Receiving a loan encourages her to earn more and grow her business.

Running a sari-sari store during rainy seasons is a challenge for Joy Ann because only a few customers go out to her store when it rains. Nevertheless, she prefers to seek encouragement rather than focus on the obstacles along her way. She believes that God will enable her to succeed on a long-term basis and be of great help to others, free from the strong hold of the past and living her life to the fullest. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends her group's weekly fellowship meeting,* where she can draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15-30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of rice and electronic load for mobile phones (prepaid cell phone credits) for her variety store

loans.name: Lea

texts.en:
Lea, a 31-year-old married mother of three children, works hard to provide for her family by running a soft drink retailing business in the Philippines. In the business for 10 years, she also earns an income from farming vegetables.

Having repaid her three previous loans from NWTF, Lea is now requesting loan of a PHP 10,000 to buy more stocks of beverages to sell. Lea aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college and expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of beverages to sell.

loans.name: Oyunbileg

texts.en: Mrs.Oyunbileg, 39, lives with her husband and two children in Kherlen, a city located in Dornod, the far eastern province of Mongolia. Her children both attend a secondary school, while her husband delivers goods to remote cities around the province using his small truck. Mrs.Oyunbileg has been operating a fruits and vegetable retail business for seven years. She sells her products at Shur, the biggest food market in Kherlen city. She rents a stall there. She buys her vegetables from wholesalers who import them from China. They are cheap, but low quality and grown using fertilizers. Therefore she has decided to grow her own organic vegetables. Oyunbileg has obtained permission to farm a plot of land and is now processing the soil. The loan she is requesting will be used to buy more vegetables to sell as well as seeds and equipment to process the land and to grow organic vegetables.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell as well as vegetable seeds and equipment to process the land and to grow organic vegetables.

loans.name: Bella

texts.en:
Bella B. is from the village of Casinglot, Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental. She is 54 years old. Bella is married and has eight adult children. To make a living, Bella owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling canned goods, beverages, snack foods, shampoo, soap & biscuits in the local community. She also butchers pigs for deliveries at houses for credit & also provides ice cubes for school canteen businesses. Bella has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Bella joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Bella is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods and as working capital for her business. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Bella from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods and provides working capital for her business.

loans.name: Leonita

texts.en:
Leonita is 49 years old and married with three children. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Leonita is borrowing PHP 11,000 through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Leonita has been raising pigs for two years and also earns additional income from fish vending.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: To buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en:
Mr. Sopheap S. is 38 years old and his wife, Mrs. Sokhan Heng is 37 years old. They live in a village on National Road Number Two, about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married for almost 10 years and have two children--one son and one daughter. Both of them are in school. 

Sopheap and his wife are farmers. They grow rice on farmland in the village where they live. Sopheap is asking for his first loan of $300 to add to his own money to purchase a motorized hand tiller. 

Picture: Mr. Sopheap S. is at home, not at the farm.

loans.use: To add to his own money to purchase a motorized hand tiller.

loans.name: Inom

texts.en:
Abdukhairov Inom is married and a responsible father of two sons. For more than 12 years he has been running house and apartment (molar) repair services. He has 2 – 3 groups who provide services. On average he has 3 or 4 orders in a month. He takes orders from Isfara and the Kanibadam region. He wants to receive his second loan from Imon International and he has a good credit history. Inom would like to get a loan of 2000 USD for purchasing necessary equipment for his business. Inom hopes that the lenders will support him.      

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy equipment for house repair.

loans.name: Berlista

texts.en:
Berlista S. is from the village of San Simon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 59 years old. Berlista is widowed and has four adult children. To make a living, Berlista owns & operates a mini-restaurant. The main source of income for the business comes from serving a variety of different meals to customers in the local community: chicken & pork "adobo", "afritada", "bulalo" & fried fish, etc.  Berlista has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Berlista joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Berlista is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients & drinks for the restaurant. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Berlista from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients & drinks for the restaurant.

location.town: San Simon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Tim

texts.en: Tim S., 30, sells ice in the busy market of Siem Reap province. She sells both for retail and bulk to her customers at a reasonable price, which attracts many clients. Tim S.’s husband assists her in the ice-selling business as well. They have four kids who study in a public school. Tim Salathe wants to buy a used motorbike for picking up her ice to sell anywhere in and around her community instead of selling from a fixed place. She would like to apply for a loan to buy a second motorcycle. This loan will help improve her business and widen her earning potential.

loans.use: to buy a second motorcycle for picking up her ice to sell.

loans.name: Darlita

texts.en:
Darlita Q. is from the village of Taguanao, Indahag, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 56 years old. Darlita is married and has four children. To make a living, Darlita owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling canned goods, snack foods, shampoo, soap & firewood in the local community. Darlita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Darlita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Darlita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Darlita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods & firewood. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Darlita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods & stock of firewood.

location.town: Taguanao, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Azima

texts.en:
M. Azima is a hard-working woman. She is married and has four children. Her husband is a farmer and has his own land where he cultivates vegetables. Azima has been in the clothing business for over 13 years. She sells her goods in a department store called «Zebo» and she has regular clients. Most of them are teenagers, brides, and recent graduates. She sells fashionable clothes and shoes and all her customers pleased with her assortments of goods. Her daughter Mahina helps her with the business.

 Azima would like to get a loan to purchase new, more fashionable goods and also fertilizers for her family’s farming business in order to better her family’s living conditions.       

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy new clothes and fertilizers for farming.

loans.name: Edlie

texts.en:
Edlie Lapitan is married with four children. She is 47 years old and had a food selling business for five years.

Edlie sells food like Halo- Halo (a dessert or refreshment made of crushed ice mixed with milk and fruits) and barbecue to their village. Edlie has been in the business for five years.

Edlie is requesting a loan of PHP 10,000 to buy ingredients like meat and soy sauce for barbecue and other fruit ingredients for halo-halo and refreshments.

In the future, Edlie hopes to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for barbecue and for refreshment

loans.name: Democrita

texts.en:
Democrita C. is from the village of Guinitan, Pagalungan, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 63 years old. Democrita is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Democrita owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from making & selling snacks & other delicacies like "puto" or rice cake, "banana cues" & hot cakes in the local community. Democrita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Democrita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Democrita is requesting a loan of 3000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed like sugar, flour & ripe bananas. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Democrita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed like sugar, flour & ripe bananas.

location.town: Pagalungan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Tim

texts.en: Tim S. is a long-time businesswoman and a low-income person. She has been operating an ice-selling business since the beginning of 2005. She owns an old car that she uses for transporting her items to sell in the mobile place of Siem Reap province. She is widowed and lives with her one kid who supports her out in the business. Recently, her old car broke down, and this is giving her problem in doing her business. If not repaired, this will impact her income. Tim S. is, therefore, asking a loan to repair her broken car. With this loan she can resume her business as before.

loans.use: to repair her broken car.

loans.name: Gulsara

texts.en:
S. Gulsara is an honest, hard-working woman who is married and has three sons. Her oldest son helps her in the business; her second son serves in the army, and the last son studies at secondary school. Her business is the family’s business: they work together and support each other. 

Since 2008 she provides video recordings of movies, music, entertainment and so on. She sells her disks in the central market of Isfara region. She works 28 or 30 days a month. Gulsara has regular customers and more orders for recording. She would like to get a loan of 8000 Somoni for purchasing equipment to burn the CDs in order to do better with the quality of records with new technology.    

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy equipment to burn CDs.

loans.name: Abd

texts.en:
Abd is a 42-year-old entrepreneur. He is married, and has four children living with him.  Abd has a falafel restaurant. Falafel is a ball or patty made from ground chickpeas and/or fava beans. Falafel is usually served in a pita, which acts as a pocket, or wrapped in a flatbread known as lafa. The falafel balls are topped with salads, pickled vegetables, hot sauce, and drizzled with tahini-based sauces. Falafel balls may also be eaten alone as a snack or served as part of a "meze".

Generally accepted to have first been made in Egypt,where the dish is widely known as طعمية (ta'amiya) in Egyptian Arabic, falafel has become a dish eaten throughout the Middle East.The Copts of Egypt claim to have first made the dish as a replacement for meat during Lent. The hearty fritters are now found around the world as a replacement for meat and as a form of street food.

Abd has been working at preparing and selling falafel since 1985. His customers include community members from his region, in addition to tourists and passers-by. Abd  says that he is passionate about his work and that he could not imagine a life without it, because it introduces him to different populations and  cultures, and it provides his family with a good enough income  to satisfy his family's needs.

Abd is requesting a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua. This will be his eleventh loan from Al Majmoua. In addition to a soft drink refrigerator, he is planning to buy new specialized machine for preparing falafel, necessary to increase his production since his machines are old and not as efficient as they used to be. He says that without the loan, he would not be able to provide the same level of support for his family. 

In the future, Abd says that he is planning to further expand and improve his business as much as possible.

loans.use: To buy a new specialized Falafel machine, in addition to a soft drink refrigerator.

loans.name: Jackson

texts.en:
Jackson W. N. is twenty-nine years old, married, and he and his wife have three children aged between ten and seven years. They hope to give them good education to the university level. 

His business is located in a busy area known as Kinanie in Kitengela. He runs a restaurant in which he sells different types of food to the local people. He has been doing this business for five years now and has one employee. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is financial constraints. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. 

He is using this loan of Kes 80,000 to buy more food items which include rice, flour, cooking oil, salt, beverages and others to grow his business and meet the demand by his customers. He hopes that in future he will be able to open a big restaurant in Kinanie. He describes himself as very hardworking, humble and jovial.

loans.use: to buy flour, cooking oil, rice, beverages, etc.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma M. is from the village of San Simon, Cagayan de Oro. She is 54 years old. Emma is married and has 10 adult children. To make a living, Emma owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as snack foods, canned goods, detergents, shampoo, soap & several kinds of beverages in the local community. She also raises pigs for breeding & sells the piglets in the future. Emma has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 12,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Emma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Emma is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products like canned goods & snack foods. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Emma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products like canned goods & snack foods
