location.town: San Simon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Magdalena's Group

texts.en: Magdalena is 25 years of age. She is married to a company worker and they are blessed with three children. They reside at Duminit, Cauayan City, Isabela. Magdalena is a vegetable vendor in their village. She's asking for a loan of  PHP 10,000 to purchase additional vegetables to sell such as eggplant, tomatoes and string beans. Through the business, she generates a net income of PHP 4,500 monthly. Her profits will be used for their daily expenditures. She hopes that Kiva lenders will continue to support her and give her financial assistance so that she will improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional vegetables to sell

loans.name: Beverly

texts.en:
Beverly B. is 27 years old and married with one school-aged child. Beverly is a farmer working in the Philippines and earns approximately PHP 5,000 per month. 

Beverly is asking for a loan of PHP 15,000 to purchase fertilizers and to pay for services to plant corn and vegetables. Beverly has been growing corn and vegetables.  In the future, Beverly hopes to make her business profitable in order to support the schooling of their child and give him a better future. She also believes that someday she can start another kind of business and improve their status of living.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and to pay for services to plant corn and vegetables

loans.name: Purevsuren

texts.en:
Purevsuren is a 29-year-old divorcee who lives with her only son in Darkhan, the second largest city of Mongolia. They live in a one-bedroom communal apartment house. Her son Undrakh studies in elementary school. Purevsuren works in a metallurgical factory as a line operator. Her parents help her to look after the child during her work hours. Her job is low paid and it's the only source of her family's livelihood. 

Recently Purevsuren had a talk with her father and elder brother about the grain-growing business and they have decided to grow wheat to earn extra income by harvesting and selling the grain. The area around the Darkhan city is agriculturally dominated, growing wheat and other grain, and the soil is very fertile. The loan Purevsuren is asking will be used to cultivate the soil, to buy seed and sow it to grow wheat.

loans.use: To cultivate the soil, buy seeds and sow them to grow wheat.

loans.name: Tabitha

texts.en:
Tabitha W. Gathoni is a married lady with three children aged eleven, eight and five years old. She owns and manages a woodwork shop where she sells wood whether in small or big pieces to clients like carpenters who later reuse it for other jobs. She has been in this business for four years and gets a profit of Kshs 18,000 per month.

She is now applying for her second loan from KADET after she successfully completed her first loan repayment. She plans to use this money to open up another outlet where she will be able to sell wood to her clients. This investment should give her good returns and she anticipates using the income to reinvest in her activities and develop her family.

In future she hopes to build her own home and business premises.

loans.use: To open another outlet where she can sell her wood to carpenters and others.

loans.name: Fely

To make a living, Fely owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as canned goods, snack foods, beverages, shampoo, soap & biscuits in the local community. Fely has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Fely joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fely has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Fely is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods & beverages. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Fely from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 34 years old; he lives with his wife and his 19-year-old son.  To earn a living, he runs a retail shop.  He has been in the business for four years.  

He has benefited from Faulu Kenya because he was able to build rental houses with his previous loans.  He hopes to have a wholesale business in the future.  He has requested 80,000 Kes to buy maize flour, sugar and cooking fat.

loans.use: To buy maize flour, sugar and cooking fat.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy a motorbike for her kids to ride to school as well as going anywhere.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en: Nancy is 42 years old, married, and has four children.  She does printing so as to earn a living.  She has over ten years in the business.  Besides that, she does farming to earn extra income.  Since she became a member of Faulu Kenya, she has become more focused in her business and she hopes to add printers.  She needs 70,000 Kes to buy a computer and printing paper.

loans.use: To buy a computer and printing paper.

loans.name: Magdalina

texts.en:
Magdalina V. is from the village of Villalin, Pana-on, Misamis Occidental. She is 47 years old. Magdalina is married and has eight adult children. To make a living, Magdalina owns and operates a business venture making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Magdalina has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Magdalina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Magdalina is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to cook food for sale. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Magdalina from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Ma. Lourdes

texts.en:
Ma. Lourdes is 24 years old and has a common-law husband. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. 

Ma. Lourdes has a fish stall business in the Philippines. Ma. Lourdes has requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to buy more fish to sell in her fish stall.

Ma. Lourdes has been in this business for six years.  In the future, Ma. Lourdes would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell in her food stall

loans.name: Dionisio

texts.en:
Dionisia is 30 years old and married with four children.

She earns a living by farming corn and vegetables in the Philippines. Dionisia is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Dionisia has been farming corn and vegetables for 15 years and also earns additional income from selling coconut wine.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Maksatbek

texts.en:
Maksatbek B. is 40, married and has three children. He earns his living through agriculture and, in the summer seasons, he works as a stockkeeper for the local area.  His wife helps Maksatbek in their cattle-breeding  business.  

Starting with the initial capital of 30.000 KGS, they managed to develop a farm with cows, sheep, goats and horses. With the revenues from this activity, they were able to buy a house in Min-Bulak village. 

Maksatbek has applied for a loan of 60.000 KGS to purchase more cattle. With the revenue, he plans to buy equipment for further developing his business. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target an especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Badassawé

texts.fr: Agée de 36 ans et mère de deux enfants, elle est mariée à un transporteur. Elle est couturière  de profession et s’adonne aussi  au commerce de produits de mercerie(fil,tissu...) Elle s’approvisionne à Lomé et revend dans son atelier dans un quartier de la ville. C’est une femme courageuse  qui se bat au quotidien pour entretenir son foyer.
texts.en: Aged 36 and the mother of two children, Badassawé is married to a trucker. She is a trained seamstress and also sells sewing notions such as thread, cloth, etc. She buys her merchandise in Lomé and resells it in her workshop in one of the city neighborhoods. She is a courageous woman who struggles on a daily basis to maintain her household.

loans.use: to buy sewing notions.

loans.name: Julieto

texts.en:
Julieto G. is from the village of Lower Tiaparak, Tambulig Zamboanga Del Sur. He is 47 years old. Julieto is married and has seven school-aged children. 

To make a living, Julieto owns and operates a motorcycle transport service. Julieto has been engaged in his business for over six years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Julieto joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his business and living situation. Julieto has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase tires and other accessories. 

Julieto is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to repair his existing engine. This will be the tenth loan taken out by Julieto from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches   covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair his motorcycle engine.

location.town: Lower Tiparak, Tambulig, Zamboanga Del Sur

In 2006, Rebie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Rebie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. 

Rebie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This will be the third loan taken out by Rebie from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches  covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Heng

texts.en: Heng C. is a 39-year-old married woman with two children, both of whom still go to school. Heng C. is a professional teacher at a local school in Kompong Cham province. She is a salaried employee. Her husband earns a daily income by driving his motor taxi, and his income helps assist Heng C. with the family expenses. Heng C. seeks a loan from Kiva to build a new cage and to buy pig-food, chicken-feed, piglets and chicken for raising. She will sell them out when they grow up.

loans.use: to build a new cage, and buy pig-food, chicken-feed, piglets and chicken for raising.

loans.name: Datévi Délali

texts.fr: Marié a une revendeuse, Datevi a 26 ans et papa d un enfant.il est mécanicien automobile et revendeur de pièces détachées auto depuis 2006.il s’approvisionne de ces pièces dans le pays  pour effectuer à bien son activité.cet prêt va lui permettre d’acheter un véhicule d’occasion et des pièces automobiles pour mener parfaitement les dépannages.il à reçu une bonne formation et aimerait en faire profiter la population.
texts.en: Married to a wife engaged in sales, Datevi is 26 and the father  of one child. He is an automobile mechanic and has been selling automobile spare parts since 2006. He buys the spare parts in country so that he can do well at his business. This loan will allow him to buy a used car and some automobile spare parts to take good care of cars that have broken down. He got good training and would like to let those around him take advantage of this.

loans.use: to buy a used car and some spare parts.

loans.name: Jeanette

texts.en:
Jeanette B. is from the village of San Isidro, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 41 years old. Jeanette is married and has four school-aged children. 

To make a living, Jeanette makes and sells a variety of food products like fried chickens and banana cues (deep-fried bananas covered with caramelized brown sugar). Jeanette has been engaged in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 7,500 PHP a month.

In 2009, Jeanette joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Jeanette has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional ingredients and for working capital. 

Jeanette is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed like chicken meat and ripe bananas. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Jeanette from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients like chicken meat and ripe bananas.

loans.name: Zagdsuren

texts.en:
Mrs. Zagdsuren U. is a 44-year-old widow who lives with her four children in Darkhan, the second largest city of Mongolia. She owns a land plot and a small family house.  

She works as a manager in the local restaurant and is raising her children on her own. Her eldest son has just been recruited by the local police department as a policeman and he is not married yet. The second son is a university student and the two youngest attend a secondary school. 

The house where they live is old and hasn’t been renovated for many years. The roof started leaking as well. The loan Zagdsuren is taking will be used to replace the roof tiles and to do some face-lift to the house.

loans.use: To replace the roof tiles and to do some face-lift to the house.

loans.name: John Fonyam

texts.en:
John Fonyam D. is 72 years, a polygamist and father of 10, three of which are under 15. Many of the others are unemployed due to low levels of education. Due to ill health, poverty and the death of some of his close relatives within the past years, he decided to join GHAPE in the year 2008. 

With this loan, he plans to repair his pig sty, buy piglets, pig feed, and medication. Pig rearing is something he has been into for a long time now and he knows how to go about it. John Fonyam has also attended training sessions on pig farming provided by local and international NGOs.

The major problem facing pig farmers now is the African swine fever but with the proper hygiene and vaccine, this can be avoided. 
 
Of all locally reared animals, pigs are the most demanded and the most expensive, assuring him of a ready market at the end. 

The profit he gets from the loan will be used to educate his children and provide food for his family. He prefers a loan from GHAPE because of the long recovery period, which enables him to repay without stress.

About GHAPE 
The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: to purchase piglets and medication and to repair the pig sty.

loans.name: Wishnie Jean

texts.en:
Wishnie Jean G. is from the village of Inroad, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 26 years old. Wishnie Jean is married and has two school-age children. Wishnie Jean owns and operates an agricultural business, raising pigs for sale. Wishnie Jean has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2011, Wishnie Jean joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Wishnie Jean is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be her first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase spare bicycle parts for his bicycle-repair business

loans.name: Fredrick

texts.en: Fredrick O. E. is a young, married man with two children, ages 8 and 5. He hopes to give them a good education to the university level. His business is located in a busy area in Kitengela. Fredrick runs a fiberglass shop in which he makes carvings and sells them to local people and tourists. He has been doing this business for three years now and has one employee. He says that this business is profitable and that financial constraints are his major challenge. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using this loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy fiberglass to make nice carvings to sell. He loves his work and says that in the future he hopes to start his own fiberglass factory. He describes himself as very hardworking, determined, and results oriented.

loans.use: Fibre glass

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en: Concepcion is 56 years old and married. She has four children. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Concepcion is borrowing 12,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs. She has been raising pigs for six years. She earns additional income from vulcanizing. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Kokou

texts.fr: MR Kokou  a 28 ans et comme profession principale il est Administrateur Réseau .il est célibataire et aimerait avoir une vie stable et bien assise  avant de se lancer dans la vie de couple. Il a une activité parallèle à sa profession celle de la vente de basins et ce crédit lui permettra  d’acheter en quantité cet article pour satisfaire les besoins de ses clients.
texts.en: Mr. Kokou is 28 and his main job is working as a network administrator. He is single and would like to have a good, stable lifestyle before he marries. He has a secondary job at the same time as his profession, that of selling lengths of damask cloth ("bazin"). This loan will allow him to buy a good quantity of these fabrics so as to satisfy the needs of his clientele.

loans.use: to buy lengths of good quality "bazin" (damask cloth).

loans.name: Fedelita

texts.en: Fedelita is 45 years old. She is married and has two children. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Fedelita is borrowing 18,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) through NWTF to buy additional piglets and feed for her pigs. Fedelita has been raising pigs for 14 years and earns additional income from a sari-sari store. She is working tirelessly toward attaining her dream, which is to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: to buy additional piglets and feed

loans.name: Loun

texts.en: The man shown in the picture above is Loun M., a 31-year-old farmer residing in the rural area of Kompong Cham province. He plants different kinds of rice crops following the rainy and dry seasons. His wife works in a factory. Loun M. is looking for a $750 loan as capital to support his farming business. He will use the loan to buy a cow to plow the farmland. Loun M. has a child who is attending school.

loans.use: to buy a cow to plow the farmland.

loans.name: Romela

texts.en:
Romela S. is 47 years old and married with four children.

Romela works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 29,500 loan through NWTF to buy more stock to sell in her sari-sari store.

Romela has borrowed and paid 20 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for 11 years and also earns an income from fish vending.

Romela aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy more stock to sell in her sari-sari store.

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Rosario Rigo is married and 55 years old with three adult-aged children. She has a retail shop where she sells a variety of products. Rosario has this business for three years.

Rosario Rigo is requesting a loan of PHP 35,000 to purchase additional products like soft drinks, spices and bread to sell in the community. Each month, Rosario earns about PHP 10,000 doing this type of work.

In the future, Rosario hopes that her business will expand to support the needs of her family.

loans.use: To purchase products to sell like soft drinks, spices and bread

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine T. is 39 years old and married. She has three children.

Josephine works very hard to provide for them. She runs a sari-sari (general) store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy items like milk, groceries, etc., to sell in her general store.

Josephine has borrowed and repaid three loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for four years and also earns an income from selling animal feed.

Josephine aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: To buy items to sell in her sari-sari store.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Godfrey

texts.en:
Godfrey N. is a businessman who does photography to earn a living.  He is able to provide for his wife and four children with the income from his work. 

Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has gained a lot of business knowledge, which has helped him to run his business better. He aspires to own a studio in the future.  

He has requested a loan of  50,000 KES to buy tapes for video, films and batteries.

loans.use: To buy tapes for video, films and batteries.

loans.name: Nilda

texts.en:
Nilda R. is 50 years old and single.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Nilda is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Nilda has been raising pigs for 15 years and also earns additional income from food vending.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough to provide a secure future.

loans.use: To buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Elias

texts.en:
Elias is a 48-year-old entrepreneur. He is married with four children living with him. 

Elias used to be a soldier but he wanted to retire and stay near his family, as he believes he's getting old for military work and wants to rest. He bought his car and got his license since he retired from the military. He has been working as a taxi driver for the past four years.  

Elias is good at his work, since he loves communication, and he works hard on improving his business and expanding it. This type of work is important in Lebanon because, in addition to tourists,  many people prefer to use a taxi rather than their own cars to avoid traffic and parking problems. His customers include neighbors and friends, tourists and anyone in need of such service. 

Elias is requesting a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua for the second time, with a good repayment history. Elias will continue to develop his business, but he will use this loan primarily to pay for his children's school expenses.

loans.use: To pay for his children's school fees.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fish

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is 30 years old, married, and has a four-year-old child. She provides services such as printing and photocopying to earn a living. Besides that, she runs a primary school to supplement her income. Through Faulu Kenya, she has managed to improve her business. She hopes to open another school in the future. She needs 50,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy a photocopy machine and a laptop.

loans.use: to buy photocopy machine and a laptop.

loans.name: Anna Marie

texts.en:
Anna Marie R. is from the village of Taraka, Jimenz, Misamis Occidental. She is 28 years old. Anna Marie is married and has three school-aged children. Anna Marie has a store that sells mobile phone credit loads (prepaid talking and texting) in the local community. Anna Marie has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 20,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. 

In 2010, Anna Marie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Anna Marie is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional cellphones and electronic loads for sale. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Anna Marie from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC: 

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional cellphone and electronic load for sale

loans.name: Gerly

texts.en:
Gerly is 39 years old and married with five children. 

Gerly works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 22,000 Philippine peso (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy items like bread, sardines, groceries, etc. to sell in her general store. 

Gerly has borrowed and repaid three loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for one year and also earns an income raising pigs. 

Gerly aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items to sell in her general store

loans.name: Angelino

texts.en:
Angelino is 51 years old and married with eight grown children. He is a farmer working in the Philippines. His wife helps him till their farm lot. He has been raising rice for five years already. He earns approximately PHP 50,000 average net income per cropping or for every five months.

Angelino is applying for a loan amounting to PHP 15,000 that he will use to purchase a variety of rice and fertilizers. He hopes to harvest more crops by the next cropping season. He is doing his best to make further improvement in the business for the welfare of his family.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of rice and fertilizers

loans.name: Ami

texts.fr: Agée de 31 ans, cette jeune dame est mariée à un pasteur et est mère de 03 enfants. Elle s’est lancée dans la vente de produits cosmétiques depuis 2007.elle s’approvisionne sur place et revend de manière ambulante .ce prêt servira à renflouer son activité et survivre au quotidien.
texts.en: Aged 31, this young woman is married to a pastor and is the mother of three children. She got into the business of selling cosmetics in 2007. She buys her merchandise right where she lives and sells it on foot, walking through the streets. This loan will allow her to bail out her business and survive from day to day.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 32-year-old Lebanese married man living with his wife. He has owned a gas shop since 1998. He works closely with a gas company where he fills up bottles with gas and sells them to customers and some local markets. In parallel, he has owned a small grocery shop since 2000 where he sells daily and dairy products. This man contributes with all his efforts in order to satisfy his family needs in cooperation with his wife who works as a teacher in a local school.

 He has obtained three Kiva loans and has been an excellent client with punctual payments. Today, he is requesting to borrow $ 1800 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to increase his purchases. In the future, he would like to purchase a car in order to enlarge his gasoline distribution operation geographically.

loans.use: to expand his purchases of gas.

loans.name: Ramil

texts.en:
Ramil F. is from the village of Libertad. He is 35 years old. Ramil is married and has five school-aged children. Ramil has a general store that from sells daily use products such as shampoo, soap, & toothpaste in the local community. Ramil has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately 1000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. 

In 2010, Ramil joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to do business. Ramil has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. Ramil is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional goods like soft drinks, canned goods, and noodles. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Ramil from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About GDMPC: 

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy goods like soft drinks, canned items, and noodles

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 44-year-old married woman living with her husband and four young children who are still attending school. She is from Lebanon. She opened a mini-market in her town in 2009. She sells all types of food products and drinks. She is thankful for her decision to start a new business; it allows her to make a good income. 

Today, she is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to increase her store’s inventory. She is intent on further enlarging her business and hopes that the coming years will continue to bring her positive growth and increased sales.

loans.use: to increase her store’s inventory.

loans.name: Joshua

texts.en:
Joshua K. Kongua is married and has one child.  He runs a hardware shop.  He is able to provide for his family with the income he earns from his business.  He also operates a motorbike transport business to supplement his income.  Joshua was previously operating a retail shop.  He is very grateful to Faulu Kenya because he has managed to expand his business.  He aspires to own a wholesale business in the future.  He is requesting a loan for
50,000 KES, which he will use to purchase nails, brushes, and paints.

loans.use: To purchase nails, brushes, and paints

loans.name: Mary Grace

texts.en:
Mary Grace O. is 41 years old, married and has three children who are all in school. Her oldest child is in university. She lives with her family in  Caloocan City. She makes her living running a “sari-sari” (or variety) store which she takes great pride in keeping well stocked. She works on her own and earns about PHP 11,800 a month. She is applying for a loan of PHP 10,000 to buy more items such as rice and groceries to sell to her customers. She is grateful for the help she receives from Kiva lenders and vows to continue working as hard as possible. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell in her store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a hair-cutting machine and an electric extension.

loans.name: Nguyễn

texts.en: Hoa Thi Nguyen is a 52 year-old-woman who lives with her two children in Yen phong district. She joined SEDA's credit program in 2009. When she received her first loan of  5,152,000 VND, she invested in opening a small restaurant  that serves breakfast. Her business has developed since then and has created stable income for her to manage her family expenses. She has been a good re-payer since the time she joined SEDA's credit program. To expand her business activity further, she wants to  borrow a loan of 9,184,000 VND.

loans.use: To expand more her business activity

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 37-year-old single woman from Lebanon. She is living with one parent. She has owned a mini-market since 1997. She sells daily and dairy products, drinks, breads, sweets, etc. Her mini-market is located in a strategic place where there are lots of customers passing by. She is the main income source of the family. 

Today, she is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to increase her store’s inventory. She is confident that the loan will help her improve her work and she feels very positive about her business potential for the coming years.

loans.use: to increase her store’s inventory.

loans.name: Lilet

texts.en:
Lilet P. is from the village of Sto. Niño. She is 45 years old. Lilet is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Lilet owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling wood & wood-related products in the local community. Lilet has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Lilet joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lilet has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase new items to expand product offering. Lilet is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional lumber for sale. This will be the third loan taken out by Lilet from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches  covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional lumber for sale.

loans.name: Olivia

texts.en:
Olivia C. is 52 years old, married, and has nine children, five of whom attend school and four of whom are working.  They live in Caloocan City. Olivia runs a sari-sari (variety) store, much like many of her fellow community partners in CCT.  Aside from selling daily essentials such asseasonings and canned goods, Olivia also sells feeds for pig raisers. She earns money from this business since many in her community raise pigs for a living. With a store in the village where she lives in, Olivia earns 7,200 a month. Being a hardworking micro entrepreneur, Olivia gains training on business as well as spiritual nourishment from fellowships in CCT. 

To help her continue the operation of her business, Olivia is requesting a loan for 20,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase more stocks of feeds for sale to pig raisers, as well as cases of soft drinks and boxes of grocery items, such as detergents and canned tuna, for her store. Olivia says that the loan will support her in gaining her strength no matter what situation her business might get into.

One challenge Olivia faces is whenever storms arise, which happen frequently in the Philippines. This leads to fewer customers and thus less income. The rains prevent her from making money on a daily basis, but she is learning to accept whatever challenge life might give her. This is because her main inspiration is her children, whom she wants to finish their schooling. It is her ultimate desire for her family to prosper.  As a CCT Community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship meeting where she can draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to purchase grocery items for her store

loans.name: Nguyễn

texts.en: Nguyen Thi Hien is a 36-year-old woman with 2 children who is living in Yen Phong district. She has been with our credit program since 2007. Nguyen invested in opening a small restaurant that serves breakfast. Her business has developed more and more and has created a stable income for her to manage her family life. Since participating in our credit program, Nguyen has always repaid her loans on time.  For new loan cycle, she wants to borrow a loan of 9,184,000 VND to  buy more  kitchen equipment  to ensure the hygienic  standard.

loans.use: to buy more kitchen equipment  to ensure the hygienic  standard

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 39-year-old married man from Lebanon. He is living with his wife and one young child. He is an experienced furniture painter; he has owned his shop for almost three years. He is very talented and completes his work in contemporary ways. He is the main income provider for his family. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $2000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase a new air compressor and other necessary tools. He obtained his first Kiva loan and he was very thankful for the results. He hopes that this loan will also positively impact his work. In the future, he is looking to further expand his business.

loans.use: purchase a new air compressor and other necessary tools.

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en:
Concepcion A. is 49 years old, married to a carpenter and has four children, some of whom are employed. She lives with her family in Caloocan City, Metro Manila. Conception makes a living selling usable junk as well as bottles and old newspapers for recycling. She also runs a “sari-sari” (or variety) store in an area adjacent to her house. She earns about PHP 12,000 and is applying for a loan of PHP 22,000 to keep both of her businesses operating and reach her goal of earning a greater profit. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: to buy supplies for a variety store and a recycling business.

loans.name: Nguh Humphred

texts.en:
Nguh Hunphred M. was born on the 20th of August, 1968. He is married and a father of five children, who are all above the age of fifteen. He lives in a six-bedroom house with his wife and six children. He is resident in Tudig, a village in Momo Division in the North West Region of Cameroon.

Hunphred’s father died, leaving the entire family responsibilities on him and making things very difficult for him. It has not been easy with him at all since his father died and he has been having very difficult times due to poverty and lack of the means to take care of his family. He has received and repaid loans from GHAPE twice.  

He joined GHAPE in 2008 and used the first loan on a restaurant business. The second loan was used to pay his children’s school fees. He says that GHAPE has helped him to educate his children because he used the profit from his loans to educate his children. His standard of living and that of his family has greatly increased ever since he joined GHAPE.

He intends to use this third loan to construct a house part of which he will rent out to tenants and part to do his own business. He is very convinced that this business is going to succeed because the plot is located close to the road and there is high demand for houses close to the road. He will use the profit from this business to expand his business, provide medication for his family, and pay school fees for his children.

He prefers a GHAPE loan because of the frequent training he receives and also because the interest rate is lower as compared to other financial institutions in Cameroon. Also, the loan is repaid in bits, making it very easy on the member.

About GHAPE 

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community in its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: to build a rental house.

loans.name: Lengkoem

texts.en:
Mrs. Lengkoem Y. (pictured with her loom) is 56 years old and her husband, Mr. Lan Tan is 61 years old. They live in a village across the Mekong River, approximately twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1974 and have six daughters. One is married and lives outside the family home, two are hairdressers, one has full-time employment and other two assist their mother in her business. 

Lengkoem is a silk weaver, while her husband is a vegetable and rice farmer. She is asking for her first loan of $1,000 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase timber for furniture business.

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda P., 42, is another persevering community partner of CCT*. Running a micro business of her own, Rosalinda also keeps a marriage with Wilfredo, a taxi driver. Together they have two children who are both in college. Their family resides in Caloocan City, Metro Manila.

Raising pigs for sale is the main business of Rosalinda. This business works well because the community consumes pork almost every day. Aside from this, she also buys quality materials like household items, clothes, and accessories and sells them for a  profit. This business is also referred to as Ready-to-Wear (RTW) business.  Rosalinda has juggled these two businesses for two years now and manages to do so without hiring employees. She earns around Php 11,600 monthly.

To help her continue operation of her businesses, she is requesting a 24,000 PHP loan. Rosalinda observes that her finances need to be leveled up in order for her to purchase more than the usual quantities of clothes, accessories, and household items for sale. She also plans to use the loan in purchasing sufficient feed for her pigs to grow healthy. Rosalinda says that the loan helps her a lot in striving more to achieve more.

Calamities are a primary struggle for Rosalinda, as these are something she has no control over. However, she stays strong in the Lord, knowing that the love of the Lord will sustain her and will shower His blessings upon her. She continually prays for peace and harmonious relationships with her family and loved ones.  As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for hog feed and apparel ordered in advance by her customers.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 43-year-old married man and the father of four school-aged children. He is from Lebanon. He has worked as a freelance bread distributor since 2000. He delivers tasty Lebanese breads to people from his town and its neighboring villages. This will be his second Kiva loan. He notes that he has indeed increased his business productivity and income since taking the first loan. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $ 2000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase a new van in order to continue expansion of his business and deliver his products on a wider range.  His income is important to help support his wife and four children.

loans.use: to purchase a new van.

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita A. is 56 years old, married, has one child and makes a living by running a sari-sari (or variety) store. In addition to this store, which she has run for the past three years, she also rents out karaoke machines for special occasions and runs a “carinderia” (or food stall). She has two employees and earns about PHP 10,000 a month.

She is applying for a loan for PHP 12,000 from CCT* to add additional items to the menu at her food stall and to buy new items such as ice cream to sell in her sari-sari store. In particular, she would like to make halo-halo, a Filipino dessert made of crushed ice, sweet beans, cut sweetened plantain, sweet yam, leche flan, pounded dried rice and coconut milk. Varieties include versions with slices of jackfruit on top or ice cream. Halo-halo is a bestseller in many communities, especially during the summer.

Nenita is determined to succeed at both businesses, despite challenges such as a fall-off in business when schools close for the summer. Her dream is to turn her store into a supermarket.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to expand a small variety store and a food stand.

loans.name: Idimo

texts.ru: Хасанова Идимо проживает в районе Вахдат. Ей 42 года. Она замужем, имеет 5 детей. Её муж работает в строительной кампании, мастером. Сама она занимается животноводством. Разводит крупнорогатый скот у себя дома. Она в основном откармливает и продает скот. Этим видом деятельности занимается четыре года. Кредит берет для закупа крупнорогатого скота.
texts.en: Idimo H. lives in Vahdat. She is 42 years old, married, and has five children. Her husband works for a construction company as a skilled laborer. She works in animal husbandry. She raises cattle at home. She primarily fattens and sells cattle. She has been doing this work for four years. She is taking out a loan to buy cattle.

loans.use: to buy cattle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more charcoal to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy V. is 37 years old, married to a businessman and has one child who is in high school. She lives with her family in Caloocan City, Metro Manila, where she makes a living by selling rice and running a sari-sari or variety store. Joy is also a community partner in CCT*, where the weekly Bible fellowships and entrepreneurial trainings help compensate for her lack of a formal education. She has been running her business for two years, has one employee and earns about PHP 11,200 a month.

Joy is applying for a loan for PHP 14,000 to buy a commercial space in a densely-populated part of Manila. This will give her a greater opportunity to earn money. In the future, she would like to expand by opening a second location. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God. The meetings also help her build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy a new commercial space.

loans.name: Christina

texts.en:
Christina N. is married with six children — one under 15. She lives in a six-room house with two persons per room in Kob (Acha Tudig)Momo division-Cameroon. Christina, who became a member of GHAPE in 2008, has faced problems ranging from her mother's sickness to her father-in-law. She dislikes stealing, killing, and sickness and she has taken out loans twice. This time she wants to use the money to buy oil, rice, beans, and corn. She thinks her business will be successful because of good management and no selling on credit. Her business will help the community have pre-prepared food at affordable prices. She is planning to use her profits to raise pigs. She prefers a loan from GHAPE because the conditions are better and because it has come to send away poverty in many families.


About GHAPE: The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit N. based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: to buy oil, rice, beans and corn

loans.name: Souklema

texts.fr: Mariée à un adjudant (militaire), elle est mère de trois enfants et a 29 ans. Elle s’approvisionne d’ignames et  de céréales au marché d’Anié une ville située l’intérieur a quelques kilomètres de la ville de Lomé et revend  chez elle à domicile. Elle a démarré cette activité depuis  2001.ce prêt va lui permettre d’augmenter son actif et satisfaire  les demandes de ses clientes.
texts.en: Married to a military adjutant, she is the mother of three children and is herself 29 years old. She buys her cocoyams and cereals in the market of Anié, a town located up-country, some kilometers from the city of Lomé, and resells them out of her home. She started this business in 2001. This loan will allow her to grow her stock in trade and  satisfy the demand of her customers.

loans.use: to buy yams and cereals.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase hair-cutting equipment and chemicals for her barber shop.

loans.name: Tanto Kuru Group

texts.en:
Fatu C. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. She was born in Moria village about 46 years ago and is married to a teacher. The couple has two grown children.

Fatu has been selling cooked rice, cooked meat and fish for 15 years. This is the first loan that she and her group members have applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. Fatu will use her share of the loan (SLL 500,000) to expand her business by buying cooking ingredients in bulk.

loans.use: to expand her business by buying cooking ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Nena

texts.en:
Nena F., 47, gives her full effort to making her micro business a success. She and her husband Gerardo live in Caloocan City, Metro Manila. Nena spends every day in her “sari-sari” (variety) store to cater to the needs of herself and her family. She sells mineral water so that people do not have to drink water from the faucet. And because many families typically cook their own meals at least three times a day, Nena saw the opportunity to sell liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) to meet their cooking needs. She has been in business for ten years and manages without hired employees. Every month she earns Php10, 000. Because she needs  financial help for her business, she has applied for a Php 25,000 loan. She will use this money to purchase grocery items, mineral water and stocks of LPG. She believes that increasing her inventory will lead to a more successful business. 

Nena is determined to work hard and love what she is doing to bring the success she strives for. It is her dream to make her business prosper and expand in the future. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meetings where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy grocery items for her variety store

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther A. is married and has four children. She lives in Acha, a small farming village in the North West Region of Cameroon. Due to ill health, she spent much of her business capital in the hospital. Motivated by other GHAPE members in her community, she joined the program in 2008. Since then, she has been trying to support her family through the loans she received form GHPAE. With this new loan, she plans to buy more palm oil and beans (cheap this season) to resell in the coming months when the prices will have gone up. This is a business she has been doing for a long time; palm oil is an indispensible commodity used in the preparation of almost every meal. Members of her community will no longer have to wait untill market day to have palm oil as most of them always buy in small quantities as needed. She will use the profit from the loan to pay school fees for her children and provide food and medication for her family. 

About GHAPE: The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: to purchase palm oil and beans

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Just like constructing a building takes ultimate effort, making a business grow has to be striven for. Making a micro-enterprise grow at the age of 56, Nenita Pateňo indeed works hard. She finished college and is married to Jaime, a carpenter. Their family lives in Caloocan City, Metro Manila. She is also a hardworking community partner in CCT*, where she regularly attends fellowship and receives entrepreneurial training.

Nenita focuses on her sari-sari (variety) store. With this, she meets the daily needs of her neighborhood, those menial ones like a sachet of shampoo, a small pack of seasoning, or a bottle of cold soft drink. She also has spent 15 years in this type of business and is well aware of the strategies needed to make it work in her community. Aside from selling retail products in her store, Nenita is also into realty development. Every month she is able to earn Php10,000.

One step she has thought of to help her build her micro-business is to apply for a Php15,000 loan. This will primarily help her boost her sari-sari store by including more varieties of products and diverse brands to accommodate the differing tastes of her customers. She believes that this loan will be a great support to her business capital. With your help, Nenita is another step nearer her success in business.

Regarding challenges, Nenita mentioned that demolition, poverty, and calamities in one way affect her business and peace of mind. Nevertheless, her principle stands, and that is to “strive more so that you can earn more.” It is her dream for her business to grow and expand, so that she can be of great help to her dear family. Now, put simply, that is another facet of her life that she has to build with ultimate effort.  As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional grocery items for her variety store.

loans.name: Godlove

texts.en:
Godlove is 40 years old, married to Carine Birka, and they have four children, all of whom are below the age of 15 and still in school. His goal is to give his children a good education to enable them to be responsible citizens tomorrow and be able to help him when he is old. He did not have the chance to complete school as his father died when he was still very young, leaving no one to continue as his sponsor. He has been surviving with his family from the income he gets from his transport business. 

Given this new loan, he plans to sell his old motorbike, add the money to the loan and buy a new one. The old one has been giving him a lot of trouble lately with one breakdown after another. 

Motorbikes are the most popular means of transport in his community, given the bad nature of the roads. Added to this, most of the roads are not motorable with only small foot paths suitable for motorbikes. He is of great use to his community as he helps in transporting people to and from the farms and also transports food items from the farms to the market. When someone falls sick, he is always there to transport the person to the hospital. The profit he gets from the loan shall be used to pay for his children’s education and provide food and medication for his family.

About GHAPE 

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community in its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: to purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Den-Den

texts.en:
At the age of 34, Den-den B. knows just how important savings are in preparation for the future. This is the reason that she makes effort to assure that her business will go smoothly and earn sufficient profits. Denden is married to Benjamin, a barber. They are raising two children who are both in elementary level. Their family resides in Caloocan City, Metro Manila.

Capitalizing on the occupation of her husband, Denden has begun her own barber shop and has run it with Benjamin. The shop is located along Araneta Avenue, Quezon City. Having been six years in this business, Den-den learned the strategies in making a barber shop function effectively and gain more customers. She also applies the entrepreneurial trainings she receives from CCT* as she gets encouraged weekly by attending its fellowship* meetings. Every month she is able to earn roughly Php11,000.

Den-den applies for a loan worth Php20,000 to help her grow her business. This she will utilize by purchasing necessary equipment and materials for the barber shop. Denden also says that part of the loan will go to her savings. She will make sure that all she needs for the optimum functioning of the shop will be purchased so that more profits would go to her savings.

One major challenge Den-den faces is demolition in the place where she is supposed to branch out her business. Currently she is devising plans on where to locate her to-be-opened store. This is one step towards her goal of owning both a big salon and a well-known barber shop. She works hard to make this dream happen, because the bottom line is, a successful business will mean sufficient savings to secure the future of her children. It is her ultimate desire to see her children finish their education.


*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for new equipment and materials needed for her barber shop.

loans.name: Fon Jeremiah

texts.en:
Fon Jeremiah was born in May 1964 and is married to Anwi Alice; they have seven children. Earlier, he was into cattle rearing but thieves broke into his farm and made away with all of his cattle. He then turned to GHAPE for assistance in the year 2004. He has received and successfully managed and repaid GHAPE loans four times. He presently has an old motorbike taxi which is the main source of income for him and his family at the moment. 

Given this new loan, he plans to sell his old motorbike and add the money to the loan to enable him to buy a new one. Motorcycle taxis are the most popular means of transportation in his community as the roads are very bad. The profit he obtains from the loan shall be used to increase the living standard of his family and pay school fees for his children.

About GHAPE 

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community in its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: to purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Born in 1958, Helen is a widow and a mother of five. She has been facing a lot of problems raising her children ever since the death of her husband, coupled with the fact that her late husband had two wives. Her greatest wish is to educate her children to a level where they will be able to stand on their own in the years ahead and look after her when she will no longer have the strength to work as hard as she is doing now. She fends for her family now by rearing pigs and operating a mobile restaurant with one popular food item ("Koki") produced from beans. 

Given another loan, she plans to buy a bag of Koki beans, palm oil and five piglets. She is confident her business will be successful as people need to eat on a daily basis and it’s something she has been into for a long time now. She carries her food about and sells to school children, hawkers, and day labourers.

The profit she gets from the loan shall be used to educate her children, provide food for them, and continue her business. 

About GHAPE 

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community in its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: to purchase piglets and "Koki" (beans) and palm oil.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene is 37 years old, single, and has one child. Irene still lives with her mother in a three-room house. The death of her fiancé made  her confused in life since he was planning to let her further her education. Due to poverty her parents were unable to send her to school nor make her learn a trade. All this made her join GHAPE in 2008. She took her first loan which she invested in the rearing of fowls and buying and selling of used shoes. She also assists her mother in frying and selling puff-puff (fritters) and beans.

Given another loan, she plans to buy more used shoes to resell from one local market to another. Most of the people in her community are poor and cannot afford new shoes so most of them buy only used shoes. She also plans to rear fowls with part of the loan as fowls are a fast income-generating activity because they don’t take a long time to mature.

The profit she gets from the loan shall be used to expand her business by growing fowls on a larger scale in order to satisfy more people. Part of the profit will also be used to educate her child and her nieces and nephews. 

About GHAPE 

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community in its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: to buy used shoes and raise pigs and fowls.

loans.name: Mbanga Lucas

texts.en:
Mbanga Lucas N. was born on the 10th of March 1945. He is married to Sophina Nato and he is the father of eight children, with only one child below fifteen years of age. He lives in a five-bedroom apartment with his family. He lives in Tudig, a village in Momo division in the North West Region of Cameroon.

Poverty has been his major setback in life. Due to encouragement from a friend who is a GHAPE member, he joined GHAPE in 2008. The first loan he received was used to buy pigs. He used the profit from that project to sponsor two of his children in the university and one in technical high school. He needs a loan this time which he intends to use to buy pigs, goats, and feed for his animal farm. He is convinced this business will succeed because he is very well versed in the business and knows that they reproduce very fast. He intends to use his proceeds to expand his farm, buy medicine for his children, and to continue to sponsor them in school.

Lucas confesses that ever since he joined GHAPE, his life has never been the same again. The poverty he used to suffer is gradually going away and his children’s school fees have never been a problem again.

He prefers a loan from GHAPE because the time for reimbursement is longer and the interest rate is relatively lower.

About GHAPE 
The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: to buy pigs, goats, and feed.

loans.name: Isibekezelo Group

texts.en:
Lillian (pictured with her hand raised) is a 43-year-old woman. She and her husband have four children, who are between the ages of 6 and 21. Three of their children currently attend school. She also cares for one relative.

She runs a clothing business in Kwa Zulu Natal of Emandini in South Africa. She explains that she has been in this business for years. Her main business challenge is dealing with customers who do not want to pay on time after they purchase clothes on credit. 

She requested this loan through Women’s Development Businesses (WDB) and Kiva to buy clothes for resale. She will use the extra income to help take care of her family. In the future, she sees her business growing and hopes to sell bags and shoes. 

In her comments she thanks WDB and Kiva for lending money to those who are unemployed like her.

loans.use: To buy clothes for resale.

loans.name: Ayaovi

texts.fr: Agent immobilier et marié à une revendeuse, Ayao est père de 03 enfants à 37 ans.il s’est lancée depuis 2010 dans la restauration de poissons braisées et ce prêt lui servira à acheter  des poissons sur place pour sa restauration  et satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle. Il a un talent culinaire caché et cette activité lui a fait découvrir cela.Il espère  que ce premier crédit l’aidera à redoubler sa clientèle et  favoriser ses dépenses journalières et celles de sa famille
texts.en: A real estate agent and married to a petty trader, Ayao is the father of three children and is 37 years old. He opened a little restaurant selling roasted fish in 2010, and this loan will allow him to buy fish locally for his restaurant and satisfy the demand of his clientele. He has quite a culinary talent and this business has made him discover that fact. He hopes that this first loan will help him to double his clientele and be favorable for his daily expenses and those of his family.

loans.use: to buy fish.

loans.name: One To Two Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “One To Two” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Memunatu K.. Memunatu is age 35; she was born in Moyba village but she is currently residing in Magburka together with her husband and five children. Her husband is a monthly salaried staff person and her children are attending primary and secondary schools. For six years now,  Memunatu has been selling cotton cloth and ready-to-wear clothes. With this loan, she will buy cotton cloth and ready-to-wear clothes wholesale to add to her business inventory.

loans.use: to buy cotton cloth and ready-to-wear clothes wholesale.

loans.name: Ndang

texts.en:
C. was born in 1973. He is married to Amuteng Florence and is a father of two young children. The family lives together in 3 rooms in Funam-Samtang, a quarter in the Mbengwi Momo Division North West Region of Cameroon. 

Due to the untimely death of C.' parents while he was still young, he was unable to attend secondary school which is one of his set backs now in life. Since then, he has been struggling doing odd jobs. He was encouraged by one of his neighbors, who is a member of GHAPE, to join the organization. C. joined GHAPE in 2007. He took his first loan and invested it in a motor bike business. He used his second and third loans to purchase (palm) kernels. 

Comparing his life in the past when he was not a GHAPE member and now, he says he is very fine and that his life has changed dramatically. With this loan, C. wants to buy a kernel-crushing machine. 

With his experience and the high demand for (palm) kernels, C. is convinced that his business is going to succeed. The profit from this business will be used to add to his capital, provide medication to the family, and also provide school needs for the children. He prefers a loan from GHAPE because of the low interest rate and the training he frequently receives from the GHAPE staff.


About GHAPE 
The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: to purchase a kernel-crushing machine

loans.name: Fight For Progress Group

texts.en:
Alimamy K. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Alimamy was born in Magburaka town 30 years ago. He is married to a trader and the couple has one child. Alimamy provide services such as printing, photocopying, laminating, etc. He has been managing this business for five years now.
 
With the help of this loan, Alimamy and his group members will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. Alimamy will use his share of the loan (SLL 500,000) to expand his business by buying working materials to add to his business inventory.

loans.use: to buy working materials to add to his business inventory.

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en:
Hassan is a 37-year-old entrepreneur, who is married and has 3 children. He has been renting a shop to design and sew curtains since 2008. Due to his years of experience in this industry, he has a broad customer base that includes friends, neighbors, and professional contacts.  Hassan is extremely proud of his work and believes that it is his experience that has helped him succeed. 

He is requesting a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua. He is planning to use the loan to purchase new curtain accessories that suit the new designs requested by most of his clients, in addition to doing some decorations to his shop, necessary to attract new customers. This will be his first loan from Al Majmoua. In the future, Hassan hopes to further expand his business.

loans.use: To buy new curtain accessories and do some  necessary redecoration on his shop.

loans.name: Lakrima

texts.en:
Lakrima is a 45-year-old entrepreneur from Lebanon. She is married, and a mother of four children. Lakrima has a souvenir and gifts shop. She has been working in retail for three years.
